PRAGMA foreign_keys=OFF;
BEGIN TRANSACTION;
CREATE TABLE "dictionary" (id INTEGER PRIMARY KEY AUTOINCREMENT NOT NULL UNIQUE, wid TEXT DEFAULT "-" NOT NULL, definition TEXT DEFAULT "-" NOT NULL, word TEXT DEFAULT "-" NOT NULL, indice TEXT, letter TEXT DEFAULT "-" NOT NULL);
INSERT INTO "dictionary" VALUES(1,'A','<f>vowel</f> <when>Pronounced as <i>a</i> in “art” and “father”; <m>a = ā</m> perceptibly shortened. The sound of <i>a</i> in “man” is unknown in Maori.</when> <br/>','A',NULL,'A');
INSERT INTO "dictionary" VALUES(2,'A.','<f>n.</f> <b>1.</b>&nbsp;<i>Collar-bone</i>. Usually joined with <m>kaki</m>. <e><m>Te a o toku kaki.</m></e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;<i>Perch</i> for snaring <m>kaka</m>, a particular form of <m>mutu-kaka</m>.<br/>','Ā','i','A');
INSERT INTO "dictionary" VALUES(3,'A.','<f>t.</f> <b>1.</b>&nbsp;<i>Drive, urge, compel</i>. <e><m>Ka aia haeretia e te hau nunui</m> (J. iii, 99).</e> <e><m>Ka rumaki tonu te pane ki te hoe, i te ainga hoki a te wehi</m> (T. 144).</e> Note: Two nouns are derived from this verb: <m>āinga</m>, <m>ānga</m>, <i>driving force, thing driven</i>, etc. <e><m>I te wa e rere ai te kano o te perehia i te āinga a te hau ki te moana</m> (W. iii, 35).</e> <e><m>Kitea he anga na te haku</m> (P.).</e> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;<i>Collect</i>. <e><m>Ka whakahaua e Whatiuaroa tana ope; kei te a i te rakau hei wahie.</m></e><br/>','Ā','ii','A');
INSERT INTO "dictionary" VALUES(4,'A.','Plural of the definitive particle <m>tā</m>, indicating possession.<e> <m>nga … a</m>, <i>the … of</i>. </e> <when>It is used before the dual and plural personal pronouns, names of persons or places, local nouns, or before common nouns preceded by a definitive (F.L. § 18).</when> Note: For the difference between <m>ā</m> and <m>ō</m> see the prepositions <m>a</m> and <m>o</m>. <e><m>A raua nei tama, ko Hau-maringi, ko Haumarotoroto</m> (M. xxxiv)</e>   Sometimes used elliptically. <e><m>Ka kai ratou i reira, pau ana ā nga hoa, katikati tonu a Tama</m> (T. 78)</e> see <m>tā (iii)</m><br/>','Ā','iii','A');
INSERT INTO "dictionary" VALUES(5,'A.','<f>conj.</f> <when>Denoting extension of space, or lapse of time; often very much prolonged in speech.</when> <b>1.</b>&nbsp;<i>As far as</i>. <e><m>Ka rere mai a Te Arawa, ā waho i te moana</m> (T. 71).</e> <e><m>Ka ra Hakomiti te ara, a Paritangi</m> (T. 78).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;<i>Until</i>. <e><m>Takoto nei, a ao noa te ra</m> (T. 90).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp;<i>And, and then</i>; only connecting successive actions or events. <e><m>Hoe ana mai. a ka u ki Mokau</m> (T. 123).</e> <e><m>Moe tonu, a ka ao te ra, ka hoe</m> (T. 196).</e><br/>','Ā','iv','A');

INSERT INTO "dictionary" VALUES(8,'A','<f>particle</f> <when>Used, </when> <b>1.</b>&nbsp;Before names of persons, the pronouns <m>wai</m> and <m>mea</m>, and names of canoes, months, etc.—(a) When they stand as subject in a sentence. <e><m>Kei te ngaki kumara a Te Kehu</m> (T. 85).</e> <e><m>E tawharau ana mai a Te Arawa</m> (T. 81).</e>   (b) When they follow any of the prepositions <m>i, ki, hei, kei</m>. <e><m>Ka korero atu a Kupe ki a Turi</m> (T. 110).</e> <e><m>Kua timata mai ano i mua atu i a Whakatauihu, i a Tawhaki, i a Tuhuruhuru</m> (T. 63).</e>   (c) In explanatory clauses. <e><m>Kua tupu tana tamaiti, a Rata</m> (T. 54).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;Before personal pronouns, except <m>ahau</m> (though <m>au</m> follows this rule) — (a) When they follow any of the prepositions i, ki, <m>hei, kei</m>. <e><m>Ka mea ratou ki a koe ra</m> (T. 189).</e>   (b) When they are repeated by way of explanation, but not ordinarily when they stand as subject in a sentence. The use of the nominal prefix a before ia standing as subject of a verb is sometimes found.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp;Before names of places and local nouns (F.L. § 8)when they—(a) Stand as subject in a sentence. <e><m>Ka taunahatia e Naki a Motiti</m> (T. 75).</e> <e><m>E puare katoa ana a roto</m> (T. 13).</e>   (b) Are repeated by way of explanation.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>4.</b>&nbsp;Occasionally before common nouns in explanatory clauses. <e><m>Rokohanga atu e takoto ana te kai nei, a te kukupa</m> (T. 146).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>5.</b>&nbsp;Sometimes, especially in animated narrative, merely euphonically. <e><m>Ma tona kaha a ia ano e taruturutu</m> (T. 159).</e> <e><m>Na, me karanga a koe ki a au</m> (T. 168).</e><br/>','A','i','A');

INSERT INTO "dictionary" VALUES(91,'Ai','<f>ad.</f> <when>Not generally to be translated by any equivalent English word, but used in the following cases:</when> <b>1.</b>&nbsp;In relative clauses, where the relative in English is governed by a verb or preposition. <e><m>Kei kona nga tangata i kite ai au</m> (<i>There are the men whom I saw</i>) (T. 116).</e> <e><m>Ka kitea he tikanga mana e mate ai tenei taniwha</m> (<i>He discovered a plan by which this monster might be killed</i>) (T. 110).</e>   Occasionally with passive verbs when the relative is the subject of the verb. <e><m>Ka kitea te wahi i kimihia mai ai e ratou</m> (<i>The place was found which was sought for by them</i>) (T. 121).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;In clauses expressing the <i>reason</i> for which anything is done, or the <i>object</i> in view in doing it. <e><m>He aha koe i whakaorangia ai?</m> (<i>Why were you saved alive?</i>) (T. 46).</e> <e><m>Koia i tapa ai toku ingoa e te iwi nei, ko Tatau</m> (<i>That is why this people gave me the name of Tatau</i>) (T. 46).</e> <e><m>I tapa ai tena matenga ko Maikukutea, no te mea ko nga maikuku kau i kitea</m> (<i>The place of this slaughter was called Maikukutea because there was nothing found but the finger-nails</i>) (T. 93).</e> <e><m>He nuka na Kupe kia riro mai ai a Kuramarotini mana</m> (<i>It was an artifice of Kupe''s in order that he might obtain Kuramarotini for himself</i>) (T. 109).</e> <e><m>Mo wai to wai, i haere iho ai koe i te po?</m> (<i>For whom is your water that you come down to fetch it by night?</i>) (T. 96).</e> <e><m>Te tangata nana nei ahau i maminga i haere mai ai ahau</m> (<i>The man who deceived me so that I came</i>).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp;In clauses marking the time or place of an action or event. <e><m>Nonawhea koutou nei i <m>u</m> mai ai?</m> (<i>When was it that you arrived?</i>) (T. 122).</e> <e><m>Kei te wai heru ano ka patu ai, katahi ka mate</m> (<i>It is at the pool where he dresses his hair that you should strike him; then he will die</i>) (T. 54).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>4.</b>&nbsp;With a verb or adjective denoting an action or state consequent upon some previous action. <e><m>Toia ake ki uta takoto ai i te po</m> (<i>It was drawn up on shore at night, to lie there</i>) (T. 76).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>5.</b>&nbsp;Denoting present habitual condition or action. <e><m>Noho noa ai nga tangata o tera motu; kaore e mahi kai</m> (<i>The men of that island live at ease; they do not cultivate food</i>).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>6.</b>&nbsp;With reference to something previously mentioned, <i>as aforesaid, as already stated</i>. <e><m>I a ia ai i roto i te whare o ona tuakana</m> (<i>When he was, as already stated, in the house of his elder brothers</i>) (T. 17).</e> <e><m>Po iho ai, ka whiti mai a Hinemoa ki Mokoia</m> (<i>When the night came, as aforesaid, Hinemoa crossed over to Mokoia</i>) (T. 135).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>7.</b>&nbsp;In the phrase, <m>Ko wai i hua ai?</m> or <m>Ko wai i tohu ai?</m> (<i>Who would have thought?</i>)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>8.</b>&nbsp;With <m>koi</m>, indicating a narrow escape. <m>Koi</m> rarua ai koe!<br/>','Ai','i','A');

INSERT INTO "dictionary" VALUES(142,'Ake','<b>1.</b>&nbsp;<f>ad.</f> <when>Indicating immediate continuation in time.</when> <e><m>Haere ake, haere ake, ka morunga ake taua whare</m> (T. 21).</e>  Sometimes to be translated <i>forthwith, thenceforth</i>. <e><m>Titiro ana tetehi o nga pononga, tikarohia ake te kanohi e Tongameha</m> (T. 48).</e>  When used with an imperf. verb, <m>ake</m>, unlike <m>mai</m>, always precedes <m>ana</m>. <e> <m>Mea ake</m>, or <m>mea kau ake</m>, <i>immediately, soon, in a very little while</i>. <e><m>No reira tana mohiotanga, mea ake ia whakamatea hei utu mo taua tamaiti</m> (T. 108).</e> </e> <e> <m>Taro ake</m>, <i>in a little while</i>.</e> <e> <m>Ake, ake, ake</m>, <i>for ever</i>. <e><m>Penei ka ora tonu te tangata ake, ake, ake</m> (T. 7).</e>  </e> Note: (In speaking, the a of the first <m>ake</m> is somewhat prolonged.)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;<f>ad.</f> <when>intensifying the force of some local nouns, adjectives, and pronouns: <e> <m>Ki runga ake</m>, <i>higher up</i>; </e> <e> <m>no mua ake</m>, <i>some time before</i>. <e><m>I mua tata ake o te whawhai ki Waikato</m> (<i>Just before the Waikato war</i>) (W. iv, 48).</e> <e><m>Kei muri ake ano i a ratou etahi waka e hoe ana mai</m> (<i>A little after them were paddling some other canoes</i>) (T. 121).</e> </e> </when> <when>With an adjective or participle, <i>quite, very</i>. <e><m>Pau ake nga taha</m> (T. 94).</e> <e><m>Oti ake nga papa e rua</m> (T. 35).</e> <e><m>A, ka nui ake tona whakama</m> (T. 186).</e> <e> <m>Taua ra ake</m>, <i>that same day</i>.</e> </when> <when>With a personal pronoun, <i>self</i>. <e><m>E wawata puku ana tetehi me tetehi ki a raua ake</m> (T. 131.)</e>   </when> <when>With a possessive pron., <i>own</i>. <e><m>E kore e rite ki tana ake kai, tino kai tino makona</m> (P.).</e>  </when> <when>When used thus with a pron. the order is sometimes varied, thus: <m>toku whare ake</m> = <m>toku ake whare</m><e><m>Homai te paki whero o Uenuku na hei paki ake moku</m> (T. 65).</e>  </when> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp;<when>Correlative of <m>iho</m>, <i>q.v. From below, upwards</i>. When persons or objects are thus relatively situated, <m>ake</m> always qualifies the action or condition of that which is in the inferior position in respect of that which is in the superior position; this is so even though <m>iho</m> be not expressed. <e><m>Te puna e hu ake ra i raro i te whenua</m> (T. 154).</e> <e><m>Ka whakatika ake i roto i te wai</m> (T. 134).</e> <e><m>E koutou e haka ake nei, whakarongo ake koutou katoa</m> (T. 65).</e> <e><m>Ma te pawa e ngau ake, ka mate</m> (T. 64).</e>  </when> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>4.</b>&nbsp;Implying direction to some place connected with the speaker. but not where he is at the time of speaking. <e><m>Engari, ki te haere ake koe ki toku kainga, haria ake ano he kai mau</m> (S. 26).</e><br/>','Ake','ii','A');

INSERT INTO "dictionary" VALUES(200,'Ana','A particle denoting continuance of action or state, used after verbs or adjectives. When the verb is followed by <m>mai, ana</m> may either precede or follow <m>mai</m>. <e><m>E kiia ana mai</m> (M. 58)</e> <e><m>E kiia mai ana</m> (M. 59).</e>   When the verb is followed by any other adverb, or by its object without the particle <m>i, ana</m> will follow the adverb or object, as the case may be. <e><m>E mahi kai ana ma ratou</m> (T. 78)</e> <e><m>E haere tapu tonu ana mai</m> (T. 78)</e> <e><m>: Ko Maru e titiro iho ana</m> (T. 137).</e><b>1.</b>&nbsp;When <m>e</m> precedes the adj. or verb, <m>ana</m> denotes a temporary condition, a continuing action, or an action intended to be performed immediately. <e><m>Kei runga kei te whare e iri ana tou teina, e ngaua ana e te pawa ahi</m> (T. 64).</e> <e><m>E whakarongo ana raua ki te putanga mai o te hau</m> (T. 93).</e> <e><m>E pai ana tena</m> (T. 195).</e> <e><m>E haere ana ahau ki Tauranga.</m></e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;Following a word preceded by <m>kia, ana</m> denotes continuance of action or condition. <e><m>He aha i waiho ai te manuhiri kia karanga ana</m> (T. 168).</e> <e><m>Ko te here ka waiho kia tere ana</m> (T. 147).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp;Without e it is used in animated narration of a rapid succession of actions. <e><m>Ae ana mai, haere ana: noho ana ia, tunu manu ana mana</m> (T. 95).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>4.</b>&nbsp;Placed after a noun, it denotes the point to which anything reaches. <e><m>“Ko Te Kahureremoa” atu ano, i waho nei, a, roto atu ana</m> (T. 144).</e><br/>','Ana','ii','A');

In the case of a few words the presence of the <m>h</m> does not seem firmly established, while in some words forms are in use with <m>wh</m> for the usual <m>h</m>. With the Whanganui tribe, and some of their neighbours, <m>h</m> is almost entirely wanting, its place being often marked by a break in the word. <m>s</m> of other Polynesian dialects is generally represented by <m>h</m> in New Zealand, and <m>f</m> very frequently so.</when> <br/>','H',NULL,'H');

Ka haere ka momohangatia te manu (<i>Birds are becoming scarce</i>).&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp;<i>Be diffused</i>. <e><m>Tena rawa te tiere te haere na, ara, te kakara o te tawhiri</m> (T. 193).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>4.</b>&nbsp;With words denoting number, size, etc., to indicate progressive change. <e><m>I reira ka nui haere te maramatanga</m> (<i>Thereupon the light increased</i>) (M. v).</e> <e><m>Ka hoki haere te pupuhitanga o tona poho</m> (<i>The distention of her stomach decreased</i>) (W. i, 101).</e> <e><m>Koia ka maha haere ai ona hihi</m> (<i>So his beams were multiplied</i>) (T. 29).</e>   So also with <m>kake, piki, heke, iti</m>.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>5.</b>&nbsp;Adverbially. <e><m>Ko te kumara ka horo haere i te huarahi</m> (<i>The kumaras kept falling on the path as he went</i>) (T. 136).</e> <e><m>Ka titiro haere i nga kainga katoa</m> (<i>He searched all the villages as he went</i>) (T. 184).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>6.</b>&nbsp;<f>n.</f> ma</m> (<i>The ground which was being traversed by Te Ponga and his party</i>) (T. 171).</e> <e><m>Koia tenei ko te tangata e haerea nei e taua</m> (<i>So this is the man on account of whom we have korero i te maia, i te ata whakahaere</m> (T. 150).</e>   So <e> <m>whakahaere tikanga</m>, <i>direct, superintend, govern</i>.</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>5.</b>&nbsp;<i>Search for, explore, go about to When repeated, it signifies <i>every place</i>. <e><m>Ka tukua nga purahorua ki hea, ki hea, kia haere mai ki te whawhai</m> (T. 101).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp;Used after the name of a place with a prep, repeated, <i>elsewhere</i>. <e><m>I korero ano au mo Tauranga, mo hea atu hoki</m> (<i>I spoke of Tauranga and elsewhere</i>) (W.M. vii, 34).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>4.</b>&nbsp;With the verbal particle <m>ko</m>, in reference to a place, <i>what is</i>, or <i>what is the name of</i>. <e><m>Ko hea tera maunga e tu mai rara ?</m> (M. 266).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>5.</b>&nbsp;<i>What time</i> ? INSERT INTO "dictionary" VALUES(1487,'Hotu','<f>v.i.</f> <when>(generally with <m>ngakau</m> or <m>manawa</m> for subject).</when><b>1.</b>&nbsp;<i>Sob. pant, sigh</i>. <e><m>Ka hotu tona manawa</m> (<i>He sighs</i>).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;<i>Desire eagerly, long</i>. <e><m>E hotu ana toku ngakau ki te haere.</m></e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp;<i>Chafe with animosity</i>, etc. Ka hotu toku ngakau ki a ia, he hoariri hoki ia noku.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>4.</b>&nbsp;<i>Heave</i>, as the swell of the sea. Ka hotu noa te moana.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>5.</b>&nbsp;<i>Break</i>, as dawn. Ka hotu te ihirangi (<i>The dawn is breaking</i>).<br/> <br/><h2>whakahotu</h2><f>a.</f> Of the even motion of the swell after a storm. INSERT INTO "dictionary" VALUES(1636,'Huki','<b>1.</b>&nbsp;<f>v.t.</f> <i>Transfix, spit</i>, a bird, etc., on a stick.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;<i>Stick in</i>, as feathers in the hair, <e><m>I hukia mai ra taku hou kotuku</m> (M. 330).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp;<i>Avenge</i> death, etc. Ka hukia te mate, ka ngakia te mate (S.). <m>Huki toto</m> = <m>hiku toto</m>is used in this sense. It is also used for certain ceremonies in connection with avenging the dead. Mohio tonu te tuahine kua patua e Rito, katahi ka hukia e te wahine ra nga toto o te tane. <e><m>Ka hapainga te taua a Te Wera, te taua taki, te taua huki toto</m> (W. iii, 119).</e>   So, too, <m>huki manawa</m>.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>4.</b>&nbsp;<f>v.i.</f> <i>Flash</i>. <e><m>Ka huki kei waho te ata ura, te ata mea</m> (S.).</e> see <m>kokiri</m>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>5.</b>&nbsp;<i>Glance suddenly</i>. <e><m>I huki noa ake te kanohi o te wahine ra</m> (W. v, 19).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>6.</b>&nbsp;<f>a.</f> Applied to spring tides. <e><m>He huki no te tai, ka timata te nui haere, te nui ake o nga tai.</m></e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>7.</b>&nbsp;<f>n.</f> <i>Spit</i>, consisting of a single <i>pointed stick</i>, on which fish, etc., are roasted. <m>Te Huki</m>, the name of a star.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>8.</b>&nbsp;A charm for stanching blood. <e><m>Kua ngaro a Tawhaki ki te whakatuputupu i a ia, ki te karakia, ki te huki, ara ki te whaka-mutu i te rere o ona toto</m> (W. i, 86).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>9.</b>&nbsp;A round house with conical roof, said to have been used by ancestors of the Maori in Hawaiki.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>10.</b>&nbsp;<i>Charm</i> recited over new—born infant see <m>pure</m><br/> <br/><h2>hukinga</h2> = <m>hikunga</m><f>n.</f> <i>Head</i> of a valley or river.<br/> <br/><h2>hukihuki</h2><b>1.</b>&nbsp;<f>v.t.</f> <i>Roast on a spit</i>. <e><m>Hukihukia te ngohi.</m></e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;<f>n.</f> <i>Spit</i>, as <m>huki</m>, 7.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp;<i>Convulsive twitching or contraction of the nerves or muscles, spasm, convulsions</i>, often regarded as an omen, auspicious if on the right side, or otherwise if not. <e><m>Ka mate toku ringaringa i te hukihuki </m></e> see <m>hukiora</m>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>4.</b>&nbsp;<i>Affectionate yearning</i>. <e><m>Kaore te hukihuki ki te hoa kua riro</m></e> see <m>mohukihuki</m>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>5.</b>&nbsp; INSERT INTO "dictionary" VALUES(1774,'I','<f>prep.</f> <b>1.</b>&nbsp;Simply transitive, serving to connect an active verb with its object. <e><m>Tatou ki te aukaha i to tatou waka</m> (T. 20).</e>   Also after <m>ehara</m>. <e><m>Ehara i te tikanga tangata</m> (T. 61).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;<i>From</i>. <e><m>I haere mai maua i te rawhiti, i te putanga mai o te ra</m> (T. 185).</e> <e><m>Tikina he ahi i a Mahuika</m> (T. 23).</e> <e><m>He hokinga mai no nga waka o tona iwi i te hao kupenga ika</m> (T. 141).</e> <e><m>He nohoanga moku e ngaro ai ahau i toku hoa ngangare</m> (<i>A resting place for me where I shall be hidden from my adversary</i>) (T. 54).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp;<i>Beside, beyond, wide of</i>. <e><m>Ka taha te patu i tona angaanga</m> (T. 91).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>4.</b>&nbsp;<i>In comparison with</i>. <e><m>E kore ia e hohoro i taua wahine</m> (T. 95).</e>   So, <i>than</i>. <e><m>Ko te moana i nui atu i te whenua</m> (T. 29; 4*).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>5.</b>&nbsp;Used with local nouns to form complex propositions ((F.L. § 16)). <e><m>Ki raro i te pihanga o te whare</m> (T. 78).</e> <e><m>I runga ano i te rakau e noho ana</m> (T. 147).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>6.</b>&nbsp;<i>By reason of, for want of, with</i>. <e><m>Kaore e tae te ope nei i te wehi</m> (T. 60).</e> <e><m>Aue! ka mate au nei i te kai</m> (P. 97).</e> <e><m>Ka mate a Te Ponga i te hiainu</m> (T. 168).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>7.</b>&nbsp;<i>By;</i> after neuter verbs. <e><m>Poto katoa nga whenua i a Rupe te haere</m> (T. 32).</e> <e><m>Pae ake ki runga a Rongo raua ko Haumia, maroke ake i te ra</m> (T. 7).</e> <e><m>Kua tu i te tao a Hatupatu</m> (T. 95).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>8.</b>&nbsp;<i>At</i> (of place) (in time past, or, with a negative clause, present). <e><m>E noho nei ano i Rotorua etehi</m> (T. 103).</e> <e><m>I hea koe ?</m> (<i>Where were you ?</i> or, sometimes, <i>Where have you been ?</i>) I whea koe i te ngahorotanga o te rau o te kotukutuku ? (P. 34).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>9.</b>&nbsp;<i>Upon</i>. <e><m>Ka tere a Hinauri i te moana</m> (T. 28).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>10.</b>&nbsp;<i>Along, by way of</i>. <e><m>Haere tonu atu i te ara nui naka</m> (T. 23).</e> <e><m>Ka haere mai i te tai hauauru</m> (T. 185).</e> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>11.</b>&nbsp;Connected with <m>10</m>, above, and sometimes to be translated <i>of</i>. <e><m>Whiti atu ko te motu i Mokoia</m> (T. 96).</e>   Sometimes not to be translated. <e><m>Waiho i a Marutuahu te ingoa</m> (<i>Let Marutuahu be his name</i>) (T. 136).</e> <e><m>Ka tikina i a Kae hei tohi i a Tuhuruhuru</m>(T. 36).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>12.</b>&nbsp;Denoting act, state, or condition in time past. <i>In the act of</i>, etc. <e><m>I te tiki wahie nga wahine—I te aha ia ?</m> (<i>What was he doing ?</i> or, <i>What was he about ?</i>—<i>in the state of</i> (Kaore i te ka te ahi (P. 101).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>13.</b>&nbsp;(Of time, generally past) <i>At, in, by, in the time of, at the time that, whilst, during</i>.<e><m>Kua herua ra taua tangata i te po</m> (T. 97).</e> <e><m>I te haerenga o Tama ma ki Moehau</m> (T. 94).</e> <e><m>I reira ka hamama te waha o te kuia</m> (T. 165).</e>  <e><m>I a Houmaitawhiti he whawhaitanga</m> (T. 63).</e> <e><m>I a ratou e okioki ana</m> (T. 84).</e> <e><m>Ko te uma o te kotiro i ka whakaea</m> (Pi. 133, 11).</e><e> <m>I te mea</m>, <i>when, whilst</i>. <e><m>I te mea e kai tonu ana i tana kai</m> (T. 160).</e>  </e> Note: Sometimes it is used to denote the present, e.g., <e><m>koia i riri ai</m>, <i>for that reason (he) became angry</i>.</e> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>14.</b>&nbsp;<i>With</i>, i.e. <i>having</i>. Te tangata i te puahi.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>15.</b>&nbsp;<i>With</i>, i.e. <i>in possession of, belonging to</i>. <e><m>He nuinga no te kai rangatira i a ia</m> (T. 144).</e> <e><m>“I a wai tera kaainga ?” “I a Waitaha”</m> (T. 145).</e> <e><m>Kei whea te wahi i to tatou matua tane ?</m> (T. 13).</e> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>16.</b>&nbsp;<i>In company with, led by</i>. <e><m>Haere atu ana a Kae i a Hineiteiwaiwa raua ko Raukatauri</m> (T. 38).</e> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>17.</b>&nbsp;<i>In the opinion of</i>. <e><m>Makatikai ana i a au te korero nei.</m></e> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>18.</b>&nbsp;<i>As affecting</i>. <e><m>Ma tahaki haere ai i te hau i a koe</m> (<i>Go by the river-bank on account of the wet (grass) in your way</i>).</e> <br/>','I','ii','I');

INSERT INTO "dictionary" VALUES(1796,'Iho','<f>ad.</f> <b>1.</b>&nbsp;<when>Correlative with <m>ake</m>, <i>up above</i>. When persons or objects are thus relatively situated, <m>iho</m> always qualifies the action or condition of that in the superior position in respect of that which is in the inferior position, though the <m>ake</m> need not necessarily be expressed. <e><m>Ka mea ake ratou o te whare, “E koe, e iri iho nei, korero iho ra.” Ka mea iho taua maia ra, “Ina koa,” etc.</m> (<i>They said</i>, “<i>You hanging up above there</i>,” etc.) (T. 65).</e> <e><m>Tenei ano te ora iho nei</m> (T. 65).</e>  </when> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;<when>Where the speaker is about to depart to some place, he is regarded as occupying a superior position, and <m>iho</m> is used as in the previous paragraph. Hoki ana ia kia to ratou kainga, i mea iho ia ki ona tuakana, etc. (T. 22). <e><m>Ka mea iho te tangata nei, “Haere ake i muri nei, kia hohoro ake te haere”</m> (T. 148).</e>  </when> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp;<i>From above, downwards, down</i>. <e><m>Ka tae kei te rua i rere iho ra tona whaea</m> (T. 15).</e> <e><m>Ka tatu iho ra te tangata ki raro</m> (T. 147).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>4.</b>&nbsp;<when>Denoting immediate sequence of events or ideas. <e><m>Muri iho ka hīa e ia te wenewene whenua</m> (<i>Afterwards he pulled up the crops</i>) (T. 17).</e> <e><m>I te awatea ka purea a Whakaue ratou ko ana tama … po iho ai ka whiti mai a Hinemoa ki Mokoia</m> (<i>The very next night Hinemoa swam over</i>) (T. 135).</e>   It thus forms comparatives of what may be termed inferior adjectives and adverbs, as <e> <m>raro iho</m>, <i>lower</i>;  </e> <e> <m>iti iho</m>, <i>less</i>; etc. <e><m>Katahi ia ka neke tata iho ki raro iho</m> (T. 16).</e>    </e> In this connection <m>iho</m> may sometimes be translated <i>thereupon</i>. <e><m>Mahuetia iho ona hoa ki to ratou waka</m> (T. 22).</e> <e><m>Huaina iho ki te taunga ko Kamokamo</m> (J. xx, 17).</e> </when> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>5.</b>&nbsp;To intensify <m>noa, kau</m>, and similar adverbs. <e><m>A, taringa noa iho ki te ngare a te hunga o rahaki</m> (T. 23).</e> <e><m>Kua kite tonu iho i tona matua wahine</m> (T. 16).</e> <e><m>A taro kau iho kua ngaro noa iho te ngangi</m> (T. 93).</e> Note:  When used with verbs in the imperfect, <m>iho</m> always precedes ana.<br/>','Iho','iv','I');

INSERT INTO "dictionary" VALUES(1826,'Ina','<b>1.</b>&nbsp;<f>conj.</f> <when>Adducing a fact as proof of anything.</when><i>For, since, inasmuch as</i>. <e><m>Ka mea etahi, “He atua koa, ina te ahua”</m> (T. 16).</e> <e><m>Kua tae pea kei Rotorua, ina te roa</m> (T. 149).</e>   It is sometimes followed by <m>hoki</m>. <e><m>Kua patua; ina hoki i haere tahi ano koutou, ka ngaro nei i to koutou hokinga mai nei</m> (T. 95).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;<i>When</i> (of time future, followed by the verb without a particle). Kia mahara mai koe ki a au ina tae koe ki tawahi.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp;Used to emphasise statements as to quality. <e><m>Te marangatanga ake i te wai, “Ina te kawa o tenei roto”</m> (<i>How bitter the water of this lake is</i>).</e> <e><m>E ! Ina te kino o te haka o tenei iwi na</m> (T. 65).</e>   Used thus the final vowel is somewhat prolonged, inā.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>4.</b>&nbsp;Strengthened by the addition of the particles na ra, ia, koa, the use is similar to that in the previous example. <e><m>Ina koa ko tau tu haka te kino</m> (T. 65).</e>   Sometimes becomes simply an expression to attract attention. <e><m>Ina na ! whakarongo mai</m> (T. 129).</e> <e><m>Ka mea atu te mokai ra, “Ina na! he whare ke to matou ko o matua”</m> (T. 97).</e> <e><m>Ina ia te kore ko enei tamariki</m> (M. 406).</e>   In these cases it may often be translated <i>here</i>, or <i>see here</i> now. <e><m>E hoa ma e, inaia te ra e whiti nei</m> (Wa. 5).</e> <e><m>Ina ake ano i haere ai te rongo o tenei wahine, kaore, he uaua</m> (<i>No wonder the fame of this woman spread</i>) (T. 197).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>5.</b>&nbsp;Equivalent to <m>tena</m>, in saluting a person. <e><m>Ina ano koe, e Ha na</m> (T. 96)</e>   (5).<br/>','Ina','i','I');

INSERT INTO "dictionary" VALUES(1910,'K','<f>consonant</f> <when>Pronounced as in English. The Ngaitahu tribe, of the South Island, almost invariably replace <m>ng</m> with <m>k</m>. There are a few words with alternative forms, with and without <m>k</m>, as <m>tena, tenaka; aua, kaua</m>. Our present knowledge of the language does <m>not</m> justify the assertion that the difference is one of omission or insertion. In poetry, particles sometimes lose an initial <m>k</m>.</when> <br/>','K',NULL,'K');

Kahore ano a roto o te whare kia kangia e te ahi (<i>The interior of the house has never yet had a fire burning in it</i>).</when> The verbal noun has two forms, <m>kānga, kāinga</m>. <e><m>No te kanga o te ahi katahi ka ruaki ratou katoa</m> (J. iii, 100).</e> <e><m>E pahu ana mai te puku o te tane, o te wahine, o te tamariki i te kāinga a te ahi</m> (Pi. 175, 1).</e><br/> <br/><h2>kāinga</h2><f>n.</f> (deriv. from <m>kā</m>, and so, properly, <i>place where fire has burnt;</i> hence) <m>1</m>. <i>Place of abode, lodging, quarters, encampment, bivouac</i>. <e><m>Tatou ka haere ki te kainga</m> (T. 147).</e> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;<i>Unfortified place of residence</i>, whether consisting of one or more huts. <e><m>Ka hoki ano maua ki te haha i ia pa, i ia pa, i ia kainga, i ia kainga</m> (T. 184).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp;<i>Country</i>. <e><m>Kua nui atu te kura o tenei kainga i te kura o Hawaiki</m> (T. 74).</e> <e><m>Toitu he kainga, whatungarongaro he tangata</m> (P.).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>4.</b>&nbsp;With a definite article or a possessive pronoun, <i>home</i>. <e><m>Ka hoki a Maui ki te kainga</m> (T. 26).</e> <e><m>Ka hoki a Rata ki tona kainga</m> (T. 55).</e><br/> <br/><h2>whakakāinga</h2><f>v.t.</f> <i>Make a home</i>. <e><m>Naku rawa i whakakainga nui</m> (M. 100).</e><br/> <br/><h2>whakakā</h2><b>1.</b>&nbsp;<f>v.t.</f> <i>Inflame, incite</i>. <e><m>Ma nga kaumatua toa e whakakā i te ope.—Kaua koe e whakakā i taua korero, kaua e whaka-koikoi atu.</m></e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;<f>n.</f> Band incited to a special undertaking, <i>forlorn hope</i>.<br/> <br/><h2>kakā</h2><b>1.</b>&nbsp;<f>a.</f> <i>Red-hot</i>. <e><m>Apopo, kia pena nga kiri o ou tungane; hihi ana i nga kowhatu kaka o Waikorora</m> (T. 83).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;<f>v.i.</f> <i>Glow</i>. <e><m>E kakā tonu ana, e ai te ao rere</m> (M. 82).</e><br/>','Kā','i','K');

INSERT INTO "dictionary" VALUES(1913,'Ka','<f>verbal particle</f> <when>Used—</when> <b>1.</b>&nbsp;To denote the commencement of a new action or condition, or of a state of things new to the speaker: it may thus be used of the present or future, or, as frequently in narrative, with a past significance. <e><m>He aha ia i wahi ai? Ka mate au i te whanowhanoa</m> (<i>Why did he break it ? I am ill with vexation</i>) (T. 153).</e> <e><m>Apopo ka kimi i tetehi totara ma tatou</m> (<i>Tomorrow we will look for a totara for ourselves</i>) (T. 89).</e> <e><m>Heke nei, heke nei te waka ra, a ka ngaro te ihu; ka taea te taingawai o te ihu, tango atu ki te taingawai o waenga, ka rere tupou te waka ra</m> (T. 72).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;At the beginning of a narrative, to introduce a condition, when some expression such as <i>when, as soon as, should, or if</i> must be supplied in translation. <e><m>Ka mutu te kai, ka hui ki roto i te whare</m> (<i>When the <m>meal</m> was ended they assembled in the house</i>) (T. 89).</e> <e><m>Ka ki ake a Tamure ki a ratou, “Ka kite koutou i te waka e whai mai ana i muri i a matou”</m> (<i>Tamure said to them, “If you see a canoe following after us</i>”) (T. 173).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp;With <m>tāua</m> or <m>tatou</m> it introdu<m>ces a</m> suggested course of action, with <m>almost</m> an imperative force. In this case the pronoun precedes the verb. <e><m>Ka mea atu ona tuak ana ki a ratou, “Tatou ka aukaha i to tatou waka.” “Ae, tatou ka hoe ki te hi”</m> (<i>His brothers said to one another, “Let us tighten the lashings of our canoe.” “Yes, let us paddle out to fish”</i>) (T. 20).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>4.</b>&nbsp;With te before the verb, <m>similarly</m> to kei. In some cases the verb, though <m>active</m> in form, is apparently passive in sense, and the agent introduced by the preposition <m>e</m>. <e><m>Ka te tami atu ki te umu taurekareka</m> (<m>M. 42</m>).</e> <e><m>Na ka te whai e te pa</m> (M. 126).</e><br/>','Ka','i','K');

INSERT INTO "dictionary" VALUES(1955,'Ka.ho.1','<f>n.</f> <b>1.</b>&nbsp;<i>Batten</i>, laid horizontally on the rafters to carry the several layers of thatch of a house. <e><m>Te tahuhu, nga heke, nga kaho</m> (M. 394)</e>  ; of these battens the upper-most was considered sacred, and was distinguished by the addition of the epithet <m>matapupuni, patu, tapu</m>, or <m>tuanui</m>.<e>The term <m>kaho patu</m> was also applied to the lowest batten, while <m>kaho tuanui</m> was sometimes used for a pole along the ridge above the thatch.</e> <e> <m>Kaho paetara</m>, or <m>kaho matapū</m>, the board placed on edge, running <m>along</m> the top of the side walls and horizontally across the end walls, it was considered highly improper to break this by door or window.</e> <e> <m>Kaho tarai</m>, the laths placed horizontally in the ornamental lattice work between the slabs in the wall of a house.</e> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;<i>Rail</i> of a fence, etc.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp;A weapon of some sort. <e><m>Ka haere a Maui me ona hoa, me nga kaho, hei patu i a Tuna.</m></e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>4.</b>&nbsp;<i>Sapling</i>. <e><m>Kia mau atu au te kaho tu ki te wao</m> (Sh.T. 181).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>5.</b>&nbsp; <i>Linum monogynum</i>, a plant. = <m>rauhuia</m><br/> <br/><h2>whakakaho</h2><f>v.t.</f> <i>Raise in waves</i>. <e><m>Tena Ruatapu kei te whakakaho i te <m>moana e</m> takoto nei, e; te ihinga nei, e; te wharenga nei, e; te marara nei, e</m> (S. 20).</e><br/> <br/><h2>kahokaho</h2><f>n.</f> <b>1.</b>&nbsp;<i>Batten, rail</i>. <e><m>No te whakau tunga ano ki te tarai kahokaho, ka homai he kai</m> (M. 219).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;A pattern of <m>tukutuku</m> lattice work, consisting of a number of chevrons. Compare the force of <m>whakakaho</m>, above.<br/> <br/><h2>kākaho</h2><f>n.</f> <i>Culm of the</i> toetoe, <i>Arundo conspicua</i>, or reed-grass. <e><m>Puanga kakaho ka rere i te waru</m> (M. 139).</e><br/>','Kāhō',NULL,'K');

INSERT INTO "dictionary" VALUES(1964,'Kahu','<b>1.</b>&nbsp;<f>n.</f> <i>Surface</i>. Ka ma te kahu o te wai, ka pango a runga o te rangi.<e> <m>Te kahu o te rangi</m>, <i>the blue sky</i>. </e> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;<i>Garment</i>.<e><m>He puahi te kahu</m> (T. 101).</e><e> <m>Kahu-kekeno</m>, <i>sealskin cape</i> (T. 153). </e> <e> <m>Kahu-kereru</m>, <i>cape covered with pigeon feathers</i> (J. xx, 22).</e> <e> <m>Kahu-kiwi</m>, <i>cape covered with kiwifeathers</i> (T. 153).</e> <e> <m>Kahu-koka</m>, a rough outer garment of undressed flax or <m>kiekie</m> leaves.</e> <e> <m>Kahu-kukupa</m>, <i>cape covered with pigeon feathers</i>. <m>Kahu-kupenga</m>, a kind of garment (D. ii, 365). </e> <e> <m>Kahu-kura</m>, a coarse flax cape coloured with red ochre (T. 101): this is not the same as <m>kakahu-kura</m>. <e><m>Ka tango i te kahu-whero i nga kahu-kura me nga puahi</m> (T. 96).</e>  </e> <e> <m>Kahu-mamae</m>, a garment sent to distant relatives of one who has been killed, to keep resentment alive. </e> <e> <m>Kahu-motea</m>, a cloak of mourning.</e> <e> <m>Kahu-tāniko</m>, a cloak of fine flax with ornamental border (T. 155)</e> <e> <m>Kahu-toroa</m>, <i>cape covered with albatross down</i> (T. 153)</e> <e> <m>Kahu-waero</m>, <i>cape covered with skin of dogs'' tails</i>. <e><m>Naku i kaiponu hei hoko kahu-waero mo taua</m> (M. 405).</e> = <m>mahiti</m>. </e> <e> <m>Kahu-wai-a-rangi</m>, some red ornament for the head in olden times; also a cloak woven in broad stripes of black, red, and white, as some <m>korowai</m> are. <e><m>Me pehea taku hukihuki? Me kahuwai-a-rangi.</m></e> </e> <e> <m>Kahu-whero</m>, <i>cape covered with red feathers</i> (T. 96).</e> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp;<i>Membrane enveloping a foetus</i>.<e> <m>Whare kahu</m>, a shed erected for lying-in for highborn women. <e><m>Kia whitu nga ra i roto i te whare kahu, katahi ka heria ki te whare kowhanga.</m></e> </e> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>4.</b>&nbsp;<i>Stillborn infant</i>.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>5.</b>&nbsp;<i>Spirit of a stillborn infant</i>.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>6.</b>&nbsp;<i>Young shoot, sprout</i>.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>7.</b>&nbsp;<f>v.i.</f> <i>Germinate, grow, sprout</i>. Kua kahu te witi.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>8.</b>&nbsp;<f>v.t.</f> <i>Put on</i> garments. <e><m>Katahi ka kahu te tangata nei i ana kahu whakapaipai</m> (S. 26).</e><br/> <br/><h2>whakakahu</h2><f>n.</f> <b>1.</b>&nbsp;<i>Membrane of foetus</i>. <e><m>Whanau tonu mai a raua tamariki, takoto tonu i roto i te whakakahu.</m></e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;The person who cuts the navel-string.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp;<i>White</i> of an egg.<br/> <br/><h2>kākahu</h2><b>1.</b>&nbsp;<f>n.</f> <i>Garment</i>. <e><m>Ka tae a Tutanekai ki tetahi o ona kakahu, ka whakahoroa atu ki a ia</m> (T. 134).</e>   Strictly only those of fine texture. <e><m>Ko Taharakau, e pokai ana i tona kakahu ki roto o te kaikaha tii</m> (Pi. 126, 2).</e>  <m>Kakahu-haehae</m>, a feigned retreat for the purpose of drawing on an enemy (tearing off the clothes as if hardly pressed) see <m>hawaiki-pepeke</m>, <m>manukawhaki</m>.<e> <m>Kākahu-kura</m>, (a) <i>cape covered with red feather</i> (T. 153)this is not the same as <m>kahu-kura;</m> (b) <i>butterfly</i>, probably the red admiral, <i>Vanessa gonerilla</i>.</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;<f>v.t.</f> <i>Put on</i> clothes. <e><m>Ka noho i raro, kakahu ai i ona</m> (T. 39).</e> Note: The noun <m>kakahu</m> is often omitted after the possessive pronoun, as in the previous example.<br/> <br/><h2>whakakākahu</h2><f>v.t.</f> <i>Clothe</i>. <e><m>Ka oti te whakakakahu ki nga kakahu rangatira</m> (Pi. 126, 3).</e><br/> <br/><h2>kahukahu</h2><f>n.</f> <b>1.</b>&nbsp;<i>Membrane enveloping a foetus</i>.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;<i>Spirit of a stillborn child</i>.<br/> <br/><h2>whakakahukahu</h2><f>v.t.</f> <i>Begin to grow, acquire size</i>. Used with reference to fruits, roots, foetus, etc. <e><m>Katahi ano ka whakakahukahu ake nga kai o te mara nei.</m></e><br/>','Kahu',NULL,'K');

ko Hangaroa he kawa mo te riri, engari he kawa noa.— Kotahi te kawa moana i u mai ai a Te Arawa ki uta nei. <e><m>“E Ngatoro, haere mai ki runga ki toku waka ki te whai ake i te kawa o te waka nei”</m> (T. 70).</e> <e><m>Tenei te kawa ora ka totoro kei ahau</m> (M. 303).</e> Note: In reciting, the first syllable is sometimes lengthened: <e><m>Kāwa te angiangi pu</m> (J. v, 152).</e>  &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>7.</b>&nbsp;<f>v.t.</f> <i>Perform the</i><m>kawa</m> ceremony. <e><m>Ka kawaina nei te kawa</m> (W. ii, 153).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>8.</b>&nbsp;<i>Effect</i>, etc., with accompanying <m>kawa</m> ceremonies. <e><m>Kia kawaia e ia te ingoa o to waka.</m></e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>9.</b>&nbsp;<i>Open</i> a new house, etc. <e><m>Ka huihui Ngati Porou ki te kawanga o to ratou whare.</m></e><br/> <br/><h2>kakawa</h2><b>1.</b>&nbsp;<f>a.</f> <i>Harsh</i>. <e><m>Aha rawa te hau e kakawa ki te kiri?</m></e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;<f>n.</f> <i>Perspiration</i>.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp;<f>v.i.</f> <i>Perspire</i>.<br/> <br/><h2>kawakawa</h2><b>1.</b>&nbsp;<f>n.</f> <i>Macropiper excelsum</i>, a shrub. = <m>kawa 4</m>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;A variety of <m>kumara;</m> also <m>kawakawa tawhiti</m>.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp; INSERT INTO "dictionary" VALUES(2832,'Kia','<f>ad. or conj.</f> <b>1.</b>&nbsp;To introduce a proposition. <e><m>Kia ata haere tatou</m> (<i>Let us go slowly</i>) (T. 150).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;To denote wish, purpose, or effect. <i>That, to</i>. <e><m>Katahi ka haere kia kite i te kainga o te tangata whenua</m> (T. 79).</e> <e><m>Katahi ia ka mahara kia tango maminga ia i taua kāinga</m> (T. 79).</e> <e><m>He aha i waiho ai te manuhiri kia karanga ana?</m> (<i>Why did you leave the guest to keep on calling ?</i>) (T. 168).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp;When the word with which it is used is followed by <m>ai</m> it denotes an ulterior purpose. <i>In order that</i>. <e><m>Me whakarite rawa nga hoe kia rite rawa, kia tangatanga ai tatou te puta ki waho</m> (T. 169).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>4.</b>&nbsp;To mark the relation between the subject and some future time or event. <e><m>Kia rua nga po ki muri nei ka ara ai te marama</m> (T. 54).</e> <e><m>Kia ahiahi ka puta ake ai?</m> (<i>Will he come up in the evening ?</i>) (T. 54).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>5.</b>&nbsp;Sometimes it may be rendered by <i>until</i>. <e><m>Kaua e kotikotia ta tatou ika; engari waiho … a kia tae atu au ki te tohunga</m> (T. 22).</e>   Sometimes by <i>when</i>. <e><m>Taihoa tatou e haere ki reira; hei te ngahuru, kia rupeke te kai ki te hapoko, kia takakau</m> (T. 189).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>6.</b>&nbsp;In instituting a comparison, Kia penei te korahi o to tatou takotoranga (<i>The place where we lay was as large as this</i>).&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>7.</b>&nbsp;In negative sentences, after <m>kahore, kore</m>, or <m>hore</m>, generally answering to the use of <m>kua</m> in the corresponding affirmative sentence. <e><m>Kahore kia po rua.</m></e> <e><m>Kahore matou i tapoko ki te ngahere, kore kia iti, kore kia rahi.—Kahore ano te manuhiri kia kai.</m></e> <e><m>Kahore hoki kia kaneke te hoe i runga i te mokihi</m> (Tr. vii, 51).</e> <e><m>Kahore kia kitea e au</m> (Tr. vii, 46).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>8.</b>&nbsp;In exclamations of surprise. <e><m>Kia nui!</m> (<i>How large!</i>)</e><br/>','Kia','i','K');

INSERT INTO "dictionary" VALUES(3079,'Kohu','<br/><h2>kohukohu</h2><b>1.</b>&nbsp;<f>n.</f> <i>Stellaria media, chickweed</i>.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;<i>Hypnum clandestinum</i>, and other mosses, used as wrappers or absorbents. Either this moss or the chickweed was used in cooking kumara for certain rites. E rua nga kumara, he mea takai a waho ki te kohukohu. Hence the expressions <m>imu kohukohu, kohukohu ruahine</m>, in connection with ceremonies such as <m>pure</m>, etc. Ka ka te ahi amoamohanga, ka wehe ano nga imu, te tapakaha, te imu kohukohu, te imu kirihau. <e><m>Karangatia atu hoki tau wahine a Kearoa kia eke mai ki te whakamama i te kohukohu ruahine o te waka nei</m> (T. 70).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp;<i>Seaweed</i>. <e><m>Ka murua nga rimurimu me nga kohukohu i tona tinana</m> (T. 31).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>4.</b>&nbsp; <i>Pittosporum tenuifolium</i>, a tree.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>5.</b>&nbsp;<i>Scleranthus biflorus</i>, a plant.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>6.</b>&nbsp;Berries fastened to a snare to allure birds.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>7.</b>&nbsp;<f>v.t.</f> <i>Curse</i>. Katahi ka mahia e te tangata ra tetahi hei.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp;<i>Be occupied with</i>.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>4.</b>&nbsp;<i>Do, perform</i>. <e><m>Poto noa nga karakia i mahia ra ki a Hotupuku</m> (T. 158).</e>   <m>Ka mahi</m>, an expression of admiration or approval common in proverbs. <e><m>Ka mahi te awhato hohoni paenga</m> (<i>Well done, caterpillar, nibbling the edges of the leaves</i>) (P. 38).</e> <e><m>Another use is the following: Ka mahi te pepeha nei</m> (<i>As the proverb puts it</i>) (T. 94).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>5.</b>&nbsp;<i>Procure</i>. <e><m>Hei reira koe mahi manu ai ma taua</m> (T. 95).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>6.</b>&nbsp;<f>n.</f> <i>Work, occupation</i>. <e><m>Ka kite ra koutou i te tini o aku mahi</m> (T. 18).</e>   <m>Mahi kino</m>, euphemistic for <i>pudenda muliebria</i>.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>7.</b>&nbsp;<i>Industry</i>. <e><m>Ko mahi, ko kai; INSERT INTO "dictionary" VALUES(4178,'Mai','<f>ad.</f> <i>Hither</i>. Correlative of <m>atu</m>. Used,—<m>1</m>. With verbs, adjectives, and local nouns to indicate direction or motion towards, or character in relation to, the speaker. <e><m>E ! he manuhiri e haere mai nei</m> (T. 79).</e> <e><m>E kore pea a Tutanekai e pai mai ki ahau</m> (T. 131).</e> <e><m>Whakatangi noa ngaru ka ma mai te ripa ki Tokarahi</m> (M. 234).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;Often loosely in narrative to indicate such relation to the principal character of the story. <e><m>Kua kite mai te wahine ra, karanga tonu mai … ka karanga mai nga hoa ki a Paoa</m> (T. 195).</e>   When used as above with verbs in the imperfect it may precede or follow the particle <m>ana</m>, but always precedes the particles <m>ai, ano, na, nei, ra</m>, and follows qualifying adverbs attached to verbs. <e><m>E kiia ana mai koe, ko hea tenei wahine ?</m> (M. 58).</e> <e><m>E kiia mai ana, ko hea tenei wahine ?</m> (M. 59).</e>   See also other examples below.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp;Indicating a relation or aspect <i>towards</i> the speaker which frequently cannot be represented in translation. <e><m>I kai tata mai ano, i konei na ano e kai mai ana</m> (T. 177).</e> <e><m>Ka titiro atu ki te pa e tu mai ana ki Puketapu</m> (T. 176).</e> <e><m>Kihai raua i kitea mai e te pa</m> (T. 176).</e> <e><m>Ka na te akau mai te huarahi a Whangaroa</m> (T. 176).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>4.</b>&nbsp;Indicating extension of time or space towards the speaker; often to be translated <i>from</i>. <e><m>Ka panga atu he kumara kia tupu i reira, a e tupu tonu mai nei ano i te pari o taua whenua</m> (M. lxiii).</e> <e><m>Na reira mai ano nga take o nga mahi</m> (M. vi).</e> <e><m>Tahi mai ano i te ihu, a te noko atu ana</m> (T. 50).</e>   He maha noa atu nga tangata i Waiapu mai, a puta noa ki te Wairoa. <e><m>He aha te take e noho nei a Te Tirarau ma i runga o Mangakahia, mai ano o mua, taea noatia tenei ra ?</m> (K.M. ''63, 3, 12).</e> see <m>atu</m><br/>','Mai','i','M');

INSERT INTO "dictionary" VALUES(4399,'Manawa','<f>n.</f> <b>1.</b>&nbsp;<i>Belly, bowels</i>. (For the various senses of this word (J. x, 7), etc.)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;<i>Bowels of the earth</i>. <e><m>Ka wahia te whenua e te kupu karakia a Hatupatu, kia toro manawa ia ma raro i te whenua</m> (J. ii, 224).</e><e> <m>He puna manawa</m>, <i>a spring from the heart of the earth</i>.  </e> <e> <m>Manawa-whenua</m>, (a) <i>From the bowels of the earth, so unfailing</i> of a spring. <e><m>Na, ko te puna wai i Motumako he wai manawawhenua tena.</m></e> (b) <i>Unfailing spring of water</i>. </e> see <m>mano (ii)</m>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp;<i>Heart</i>. <e><m>Na, te matenga o taua tamaiti ra, pokaia ana e Turi te manawa</m> (T. 107).</e>   Also as seat of affection. <e><m>Te ataahuatanga o Te Whatuiapiti, te kuku o tona manawa</m> (<i>Her heart''s darling</i>) (T. 164).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>4.</b>&nbsp;<i>Breath</i>. <e><m>Kua rere ake te manawa nei ki runga ki te ihu</m> (M. 356).</e><e> <m>Ka he te manawa</m>, <i>be out of breath</i> or <i>out of heart</i>. <e><m>E piki ana ano i tana pikitanga ki Maheahea, ka he te manawa</m> (M. 172).</e>    </e> <e> <m>Manawakiore</m>, the last faint breath of a dying man. Kua kore e kaha ki te korero; ka oho ko te manawa anake, manawa paku; ka kiia tena he manawa-kiore. </e> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>5.</b>&nbsp;<i>Patience</i>. <e><m>Kei te whakaporo koe i te manawa o Matuku</m> (Tr. vii, 47).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>6.</b>&nbsp;<i>Mind, spirit</i>.<e><m>E hiakai ana ahau, kaore aku manawa korero</m> (J. x, 8).</e><when>Used in a number of combinations, as follows: </when> <e> <m>Manawa kai tutae</m>, <i>daring, undaunted</i>.</e> <e> <m>Manawakino</m>, <i>internally uneasy, apprehensive</i>.</e> <e> <m>Manawa-nui</m>, (a) <i>Stout-hearted</i>. <e><m>Ka uiuia tetahi tangata tino manawa-nui o taua ope</m> (T. 154).</e>   (b) <i>Patient, forbearing</i>. <e><m>I muri i a au nei kia manawa-nui, kei kainga ake a muri i a au</m> (T. 22).</e></e> <e> <m>Manawa-pā</m>, (a) <i>Grudging, parsimonious</i>. <e><m>Te tangata e manawa-pa ana ki te kai</m> (P. 104).</e>   (b) <i>Loth, reluctant</i>. <e><m>E manawapa ana ahau ki te korero, kahore hoki he mea hei hoatutanga maku ki a ia.</m></e> (c) <i>Regretful</i>. E manawa-pa ana ia ki tona waka kua pakaru. (d) <i>Apprehensive</i>. <e><m>E kore tona kainga e manawa-patia, he waiho noa iho kia tuwhera kau ana</m> (P. 104).</e> <e><m>Kihai matou i manawa-pa ki o matou whenua, kei riro.</m></e> (e) <i>In suspense, anxious</i>. (f) <i>Anxiety, misgiving</i>. <e><m>Mau e whakamarama nga mate me nga manawa-pa i roto i o matou ngakau</m> (W.M. x, 46).</e>   </e> <e> <m>Manawa-popore</m>, <i>anxious</i> or <i>considerate</i>, either for others or for oneself; <i>parsimonious</i>. <e><m>Aua koe e titiro ki te manawapopore hei atawhai mou</m></e> see <m>matapopore</m>. </e> <e> <m>Manawa-rau</m>, <i>distracted, uneasy</i>. </e> <e> <m>Manawa-reka</m>, <i>gratified, satisfied</i>. <e><m>Ka manawa-reka te hakui</m> (Tr. vii, 37).</e> <e><m>Katahi ano au ka manawa-reka, ka riro mai hoki te utu o toku kakahu.</m></e></e> <e> <m>Manawa-rere</m>, (a) <i>Rash, impetuous</i>. (b) A starting up to attack a foe without a preconcerted plan of attack, which was regarded as an <m>aitua</m> (J. vii, 21.)</e> <e> <m>Manawa-rū</m>, (a) <i>Fidgety, anxious</i>. (b) <i>Enraptured, delighted</i>. <e><m>Ka noho a Tarewai i ro ngaherehere, ka manawa-ru ki tana rakau kua hoki mai ki a ia</m> (W. iii, 99).</e>  </e> <e> <m>Manawawera</m>, <i>excited, angry</i>. <e><m>Ka tae a Te Ikapoto, ka kite nga pouaru, katahi ano ka manawa-wera ki a Te Ikapoto nga wahine.</m></e></e> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>7.</b>&nbsp;<i>Encouragement, support, sustenance</i>. <e><m>Whakamatauria e koe enei hei manawa mou. He ika he manu anake te manawa o te iwi.</m></e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>8.</b>&nbsp;Technical term for a <i>rope</i> supporting a fern-bundle fish trap (Ar.).<br/> <br/><h2>whakamanawa</h2><b>1.</b>&nbsp;<f>v.t.</f> <i>Encourage, render confident</i>. <e><m>I whakamanawatia ki te tau, ka ai he huanga ki nga pahi</m> (<i>I was encouraged in reference to the season that I should prove a relative to my guests</i>) (M. 230).</e> <e><m>Kei whakamanawa nga pakeha ki te kupu a Potatau, kei mate nga pakeha i tana kupu.</m></e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;<f>v.i.</f> <i>Refresh onself</i>. <e><m>Ka whakamanawa a Tuna ki raro ki Te Muruwaioata, ki te wai takoto ai</m> (Tr. vii, 44).</e><br/> <br/><h2>mānawanawa</h2><b>1.</b>&nbsp;<f>a.</f> <i>Patient, persistent</i>. <e><m>Ka hika manawanawa taku ahi</m> (K.).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;<f>n.</f> <i>Aperture, space, gap</i>. <e><m>Nui ki waho, kati; iti ki roto, maikuku pango; kia mau, kei manawanawa.</m></e> <e><m>Manawanawa noa te urunga</m> (<i>There is a gap at the join</i>).</e><br/>','Manawa',NULL,'M');

Ko te whatu o te pou tokomanawa ka tapukeria ki te take o te pou, no muri mai ka heria ki te tuaahu hai manea, ara hai mea whakaora i nga tangata nona te whare (J. v, 153).&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp;Some occult connection between a man and his footprint which might be used to his injury or to increase his influence. INSERT INTO "dictionary" VALUES(4504,'Maopo','<f>v.i.</f> <i>Shrink back, wince</i>.<br/>','Maopo',NULL,'M');
INSERT INTO "dictionary" VALUES(4505,'Maori','<b>1.</b>&nbsp;<f>a.</f> <i>Normal, usual, ordinary</i>. <e><m>Tirohia iho, e hine ma, ki te parera e tere atu na; ehara tena, he manu maori</m> (<i>That is not it, just an ordinary bird</i>—it was a paradise duck) (M. 235).</e><when>Very frequently used to distinguish objects from others having special characteristics; thus, <i>kaipuke maori</i> was a <i>sailing vessel</i>, as distinguished from a steamer; <e> <m>kuri maori</m>, <i>dog</i>, as opposed to introduced quadrupeds: <e><m>Ko te kai he kuri maori</m> (T. 139)</e> </e>;</when> <e> <m>rakau maori</m>, <i>ordinary, inferior trees</i>, not finer timber trees;  </e> <e> <m>tangata maori</m>, <i>man, human being</i>, as opposed to a supernatural being: <e><m>Ehara i te mahi tangata maori, na te atua tenei mahinga</m> (T. 178)</e>; later, <i>man of the Polynesian race</i>, not a foreigner, the distinction not being confined to colour;  </e> <e> <m>wai maori</m>, <i>fresh water</i>: <e><m>Nga ika i te wai tai, i te wai maori</m> (M. lxxvii)</e>;  </e> <e> <m>whetu maori</m>, <i>lesser, unimportant stars:</i> <e><m>Takarokaro noa ana te whetu maori o runga</m> (M. 25).</e>  </e> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;<i>Native</i>, or <i>belonging to New Zealand, Maori</i> (a comparatively modern use; see 3 below). <e><m>Kaore i ata poto te korero mai nga tikanga tapu, nga tikanga noa, he mea kaiponu mai e nga tohunga maori</m> (M. lxxviii).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp;<f>n.</f> <i>Person of the native race, New Zealander, Maori</i>. <e><m>Ko to te Maori ritenga tawhito tenei, ana ka marenatia</m> (Hae. 205).</e> <e><m>Me i kore he atua nui onamata, e kore e whai atua ririki nga Maori</m> (M. lxxvii).</e> Note: This use began about 1850. Early European writers invariably spoke of <i>natives</i>, or <i>New Zealanders</i>, one of the earliest examples of the use of the word “Maori” in English (Hae. 204)being in the translation of the passage above. It appears, therefore, as if the usage originated with the Maoris themselves.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>4.</b>&nbsp;<f>ad.</f> <i>Freely, without restraint, without ceremony, without object</i>, etc. <e><m>Kua puta ia ki waho i te pito o te rua ra, kua ora ia, kua haere maori noa iho i te koraha</m> (W. iv, 183).</e> <e><m>Ka haere matou i te huarahi, a ka ngaro taua huarahi, katahi matou ka haere maori noa atu i roto i te ngahere.</m></e> <e><m>Ka maoa mai te mahi o te parera; ara i kai, i kai, kihai i aha, mahue maori etahi.—He turi maori no te koroke nei</m> (<i>Sheer obstinacy</i>, etc.)</e> <e><m>E pai ana kia peia maoritia.</m></e> <e><m>I patua maoritia ia</m> (<i>He was struck unintentionally</i>).</e><br/> <br/><h2>whakamaori</h2><f>v.t.</f> <i>Render into the Maori language</i>. (mod.)<br/>','Maori','i','M');

INSERT INTO "dictionary" VALUES(4585,'Maro','<b>1.</b>&nbsp;<f>n.</f> A sort of <i>kilt</i> or <i>apron</i> worn by males and females. <e><m>He maro aute te maro o Whakatau</m> (T. 59).</e>   The <m>maro</m> might be made of various materials other than <m>aute</m>, as above. <e><m>He maro waero hoki</m> (T. 15).</e>   He ao te rangi ka uhia; he tu, he maro taranga i taupi (P.) also see 5 below. It was also made in various patterns, the <m>maro kopua</m> being highly ornamented, and worn by women of high rank; another pattern was the <m>maro whaiapu</m>. <e><m>Ko te wahi koa i pai ai ia no te maro whaiapu</m> (T. 15).</e>   The <m>maro huka</m> or <m>maro tuhou</m> was roughly made of leaves of <m>karamu</m> for use in certain ceremonies in time of war. Terms with regard to the use of the <m>maro</m> indicated whether a woman was married or single; thus <m>maro kau</m> and <m>maro kore</m> referred to a spinster, while <m>maro nui</m> and <m>maro pūrua</m> were applied to a married woman.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;Material (moss, lichen, etc.) used by a woman at certain periods. <e><m>No te haerenga o Apakura ki tatahi, ka whiua tona maro ki te moana</m> (T. 57).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp;Fronds of fern, or twigs, used in certain rites, as <m>rahui</m>, or in connection with a new house. Ko te maro he rau otaota, kiwikiwi pea, aha ranei, ka apiti ki te kohatu, ko te aria tena o te tangata.—Ka mahia te whare, ka oti, ka poua te pou tahu o roto, ka whakamaua te maro ki runga hai taki i te mahana ki roto. <e><m>Kei te pou tuaroa te maro e tau ai au … kei te poutokomanawa te maro e tau ai au … kei te pou whakaotinga te maro tauria</m> (M. 374).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>4.</b>&nbsp;A rite and incantation for success in war and other purposes. <e><m>He maro taua</m> (M. 221).</e> <e><m>Katahi ka wehea e ia te taha mo te taniwha, he maro; ka wehea hoki e ia te taha mo te hapuku</m> (J. iii, 98).</e>   But in another version of this story recorded by Sir G. Grey the lady''s <m>maro</m> were material: Tae atu ki nga maro, he aute ko te mea ma i te aroaro, ko te mea whero i te tuara (these were eaten by the <m>taniwha</m> and <m>hapuku</m>) (Pi. 135, 3). One such incantation was known as <m>maro huka</m>, that being the dress worn by the priest on the occasion of its recital.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>5.</b>&nbsp;<f>v.t.</f> <i>Put on as a</i><m>maro</m>. <e><m>Taenga atu ki te rimu o te kowhatu, motuhia ake, a marohia iho</m> (Pi. 135, 3).</e> <e><m>Homai taku maro kia hurua kia marohia</m> (T. 98).</e> <e><m>No te marohanga e te wahine he raupo, he toetoe, he kutakuta, he raurekau, he aha, he aha</m> (M. lxxvii).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>6.</b>&nbsp;Perform the rites as in <m>3</m>, above; <m>maro</m> huka being used for reciting the special maro for war. <e><m>Ka huihui nga tohunga ki te tuaahu ka maro huka, ka tatua i te tuhou, ka whakatairangi.</m></e><br/>','Maro',NULL,'M');

calamity</i>.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>15.</b>&nbsp;<i>Desire</i>. <e><m>Ka maminga e koe he mate wai tou</m> (T. 168).</e> <e><m>He mate kai ha, ne, i hoki wawe ai koutou?</m> (T. 194).</e><when>So, e.g., <e> <m>mate kai</m>, <i>hunger</i> </e>, <e> <m>mate wai</m>, <i>thirst</i> </e>, which are sometimes written as one word.</when> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>16.</b>&nbsp;<i>Company of mourners</i>. INSERT INTO "dictionary" VALUES(4987,'Mauri','<br/><h2>mouri</h2><f>n.</f> <b>1.</b>&nbsp;<i>Life principle, thymos of man</i>. Called sometimes <m>mauri ora</m>. Apparently at times used for <i>person</i>. <e><m>To maunga tiketike, huinga mauri ora</m> (M. 247).</e>   Used in the exclamation to avert evil after a sneeze. <e><m>“Tihe mauri ora”</m> (M. 356).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;<i>Source of the emotions;</i> not to be confused with the material seat of the same in <m>manawa</m> or <m>ngakau</m>. From this comes <e> <m>oho mauri</m>, <i>start suddenly</i>. <e><m>Ka oho mauri ahau</m></e>; or, <e><m>Ka oho taku mauri</m></e>. <e><m>Oho rere te mauri, te hinganga o te hoa</m> (M. 109).</e></e>   Also <e> <m>mauri rere</m>, <i>panic-stricken;</i></e> <e> <m>mauri tau</m>, <i>absence of panic</i></e> (J. vii, 121).&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp;<i>Talisman, a material symbol</i> of the hidden principle protecting vitality, <m>mana</m>, fruitfulness, etc., of people, lands, <m>forests</m>, etc. <e><m>Koi to mauri ka tupu, tupu koe i to mauri, ka rau huihui koe i to mauri, ka rau matomato koe i to mauri</m> (M. 379).</e> <e><m>Ko tenei mea ko te mauri, hai pupuri i te hau o te kainga.</m></e> <e><m>Ko te mauri he mea huna ki te ngaherehere.</m></e> <e><m>Ka ora katoa nga kai o te kainga i tenei mauri.</m></e> In some instances <m>mauri apparently indicated the principle itself, while the symbol was spoken of as aria</m>. <e><m>Kia tau te mauri o te kai ki raro</m> (P.).</e> [On the above senses of <m>mauri</m>, Best in (J. x, 2–7), and elsewhere.]&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>4.</b>&nbsp;A young plant of <m>mapou</m>, or of some other shrub, pulled up by the roots and used in connection with certain <m>karakia</m>. <e><m>Ka hopu tona ringa ki te mauri … ka haua haeretia e ia te mauri i tona ringa, me te karakia haere atu.</m></e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>5.</b>&nbsp;Poles of <m>mapou</m>, erected for the <m>pure</m> ceremony in connection with the <m>kumara</m> crop; called also <m>toko</m>, or <m>toko-mauri</m>, <i>q.v</i>.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>6.</b>&nbsp;The name of a class of <m>karakia</m>. <e><m>He mauri no muri o te purenga</m> (M. 420).</e> <e><m>Ka whakahua te tohunga i taua mauri</m> (M. 420).</e> <e><m>Tohinga mauritanga o papa ma ki mua ki te ahu</m> (M. 248).</e><br/>','Mauri','i','M');

INSERT INTO "dictionary" VALUES(5026,'Me','<b>1.</b>&nbsp;conj, <i>If;</i> generally implying the reverse of the condition stated. <e><m>Me he manu, kua rere noa atu</m> (T. 16).</e>   Often in the form mehemea, <i>if the case were that, etc.</i>, implying that it is not so. <e><m>Mehemea na te tangata tenei mahinga, e kitea te whariki o te waka</m> (T. 178)</e> see <m>ki te mea</m>, <m>mea (i)</m>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;<i>As if, like, as it were</i>. <e><m>Me he kawau pu te ahua</m> (T. 138).</e> <e><m>Me te manu i motu i te ma-hanga</m> (T. 64).</e>   The phrase <m>me te mea</m> is sometimes used in this sense. <e><m>Heoti ano me te mea e hoe ana i te moana marino</m> (T. 117).</e> <e><m>Ko nga ringaringa me te mea ka marere</m> (T. 145).</e>   Less frequently <m>mehemea</m>, in same sense. <e><m>Mehemea ko Kopu ka rere i te pae</m> (T. 65).</e> <e><m>Mehemea ko te whare huata a Maui</m> (T. 153).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp;After pena, penei, and pera, not to be translated. <e><m>He ahua tangata, penei me te ahua pakeha</m> (T. 181).</e> <e><m>Kaore e peneitia tana ika me ta te tangata maori nei e tuhaina</m> (T. 179).</e><br/>','Me','i','M');
INSERT INTO "dictionary" VALUES(5027,'Me','<f>particle</f> <when>Used-</when> <b>1.</b>&nbsp;<when>With active verbs to form an optative. <e><m>Ahakoa nui te moana, me aha? Engari me whakamatau</m> (T. 164).</e> <e><m>Ae, me haere atu au</m> (<i>Yes, I had better depart</i>) (T. 10)</e>  , <e><m>“Me pehea ra te kumenga?”… Ka mea etahi, “Me whakawhirinaki ki etahi rakau</m> (T. 159).</e>  </when> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;<when>Similarly to form a mild imperative. <e><m>Me noho ano koutou, kaua e haere</m> (T. 195).</e>   With a transitive verb, the form is generally active, but the signification may be passive. <e><m>Ko nga waka katoa me tapatapahi nga kaha, me unuunu hoki nga puru</m> (T. 169).</e>  </when> Note: The usages <b>1</b> and <b>2</b> are not found in negative clauses.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp;<when>In poetry, apparently redundantly, with the interrogatives <m>wai, hea</m>, etc. <e><m>Me ko wai te tangata i ngaro atu ki a koe?</m> (M. 244).</e> <e><m>Me ko hea te whare?</m> (M. 161).</e>  </when> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>4.</b>&nbsp;As in the following case: <e><m>Kati me he purupuru i nga korero <i>(Leave off attempting to stifle the discussion)</i>.</m></e><br/>','Me','ii','M');

INSERT INTO "dictionary" VALUES(5029,'Mea.','<br/><h2>me aha</h2> <i>What does it signify</i>? A colloquial use.<br/>','Meā',NULL,'M');
INSERT INTO "dictionary" VALUES(5030,'Mea','<b>1.</b>&nbsp;<f>n.</f> <i>Thing</i>. <e><m>I mohio ia ki nga mea katoa</m> (T. 57).</e> <e><m>Koia tenei pepeha mo te mea kite</m> (<i>Hence this saying for anything found</i>) (T. 74).</e>   Often not requiring to be translated. <e><m>Te rongonga atu o Rongorongo ki te mea ra ka hoki ia</m> (<i>When Rongorongo heard that, she returned</i>) (T. 108).</e>   <m>He mea</m> is often used, followed by a verb active in form but passive in meaning, to supply descriptive details. <e><m>Ko te matamata he mea tahu ki te ahi</m> (<i>The point having been set on fire</i>) (T. 81).</e> <e><m>He mea heru te mahunga</m> (<i>The head having been dressed with a comb</i>) (M. Ixxxiii).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;<i>Reason, cause</i>. <e><m>He wahine te mea i pura ai te kanohi o Tahuaroa</m> (P. 29).</e> <e><m>He wahine ahua pai tona kanohi, ko te mea tera i moe ai a Paoa i a ia</m> (T. 185).</e>   Mo te mea, no te mea, or ta te mea, <i>because</i>. <e><m>Tenei kupu, mo te mea ka tahia atu nga otaota ki te taha o te marae</m> (P. 108).</e> <e><m>Ka riri a Huakatoa no te mea i rukea e tatou nga kai</m> (P. 99).</e> <e><m>E kore au e riri ki a koe, ta te mea e aroha ana ahau ki tou tinana kei mate</m> (T. 129).</e>   He mea, <i>to the intent</i>. <e><m>He kai makutu ana kai, koia i karanga mai ai i a Tamure ki te kai, he mea kia mate</m> (T. 173).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp;<i>Fact, event, case</i>. <e><m>Ehara i te mea i whanau tangata mai</m> (T. 56).</e> So in the expressions :<e> <m>i te mea, na te mea</m>, <i>when</i>. <e><m>Na te mea ano ka kitea nuitia, ka mea, “No whea mai ra te are?”</m> (Pi. 135, 3).</e> <e><m>Ka paoa e Matuku-whakapu a Para ratou ko nga taina, i te mea kua papaku nga wai</m> (W.W. 58).</e>    </e> <e> Also, <m>ki te mea</m>, <i>in the case that, if</i>. <e><m>Ki te mea ka tae mai ia ki konei, ka patua ia e matou</m> (T. 200).</e>    </e> <e> <m>Me he mea</m>, or <m>mehemea</m>, <i>if the case were that</i> (implying that it is not so).  </e> <e> <m>Me te mea</m>, <i>as if, as it were</i> </e> see <m>me (i)</m>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>4.</b>&nbsp;<f>indef. pron.</f> <i>One</i>. <e><m>Katahi ka tahuna e Mahuika ki te mea i toe o nga maikuku</m> (T. 24).</e> <e><m>Kaore i homai nga mea momona kia kai tahi ratou, ko nga mea tokoroa anake mana</m> (T. 94).</e>   Not infrequently it takes the place of a relative pronoun, and may be translated <i>who, which</i>. <e><m>Ko tatou, ko te mea i ata tirohia iho e ia te ata whanautanga</m> (<i>We who were seen by her to have been born in a regular manner</i>) (T. 11).</e> <e><m>Kotahi te mea i whakaorangia</m> (T. 60).</e> <e><m>He kai ko te mea e mate i a koe</m> (<i>It is food which will suffer at your hands</i>) (T. 100).</e>   In some cases it is used for a noun to avoid repetition, and is not translated. <e><m>Kihai i tika tona whiwhinga ki te taonga ehara i te mea utu</m> (P. 105).</e> <e><m>Ka nanao te ringa o te tohunga tuatoru ki te karearea; ma te mea tuatahi e whakatakoto aua whatu e toru</m> (W.W. 3).</e>   Tirohia mai etahi kowhatu, hei te mea nui.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>5.</b>&nbsp;Used of persons whom it is unnecessary or impossible to name. <i>So-and-so;</i> pl. mea ma, <i>such-and-such persons</i>. <e><m>“Mo wai te wai, i haere iho ai koe i te po?” Ka mea atu, “Mo mea ma”</m> (T. 96).</e>   It is also so used in address. <e><m>E mea ma, haere mai ki te mata-kitaki</m> (T. 52).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>6.</b>&nbsp;<f>v.t.</f> <i>Do, deal with</i>. Often as a substitute for a more definite word. Meatia te mea nei.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>7.</b>&nbsp;<i>Cause, make</i>. <e><m>Nana ano i mea kia pa ia</m> (T. 16).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>8.</b>&nbsp;<i>Say</i>. <e><m>Ka mea atu a Manaia, “Kau mai; kahore he wai”</m> (T. 120).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>9.</b>&nbsp;<i>Intend, wish</i>. <e><m>I mea hoki ratou kia tirohia paitia ia</m> (T. 193).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>10.</b>&nbsp;<i>Think</i>. <e><m>Ka mea a Ha, ka mate ia</m> (T. 96).</e> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>11.</b>&nbsp;To denote lapse of time, when it may sometimes be rendered, <i>go on</i>. <e><m>Me te rere haere te waka ra, a Te Arawa; mea, mea, a, ka taka kei waho o Maketu</m> (T. 74).</e>   So mea ake (often written meāke). <i>soon;</i> mea kau ake, <i>very soon, immediately</i>. <e><m>No reira tana mohiotanga mea ake ia whakamatea ai hei utu mo taua tamaiti</m> (T. 108).</e><br/> <br/><h2>meamea</h2><b>1.</b>&nbsp;<f>v.t.</f> <i>Say, give orders</i>. <e><m>Ka mea-mea a Tukutuku kia moata ki te whariki mo te kainga</m> (T. 192).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;<f>a.</f> <i>Bastard</i>.<e> <m>Tama meamea</m>, <i>son by a slave wife</i>. <e><m>Ha tama meamea noa ra koe naku</m> (W. iii, 53).</e> </e> <br/>','Mea','i','M');

Ka riro i te poriro, tiraumoko nei, moenga hau nei, moenga rau kawa nei</m></e></e> see <m>moe 5</m><br/> <br/><h2>whakamoe</h2><b>1.</b>&nbsp;<f>v.t.</f> <i>Put to sleep</i>.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;<i>Close</i> the eyes. <e><m>Ka whakamoea nga kanohi, ko te tangata ia e ara ana.</m></e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp;<i>Give in marriage</i>. <e><m>Ko taku tuahine ra kia whakamoea ma taku hoa takapui, ma Tiki</m> (T. 135).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>4.</b>&nbsp;<i>Conceal</i>. <e><m>Te whatu o Poutini, he taonga whakamoe i te whare</m> (M. 329).</e> <e><m>Ka whakamoea nga patu ki te whare</m> (S.).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>5.</b>&nbsp;Trace a genealogy, assigning wives to the males, as opposed to <m>taotahi</m>, reciting in the single line only. <e><m>Kaore au e pai ki te taotahi i aku whakapapa, me ata whakamoe ano ka pai ai au.</m></e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>6.</b>&nbsp;<i>Recite</i> traditional lore. He tangata whakamoe tau (<i>A man who has knowledge of the seasons</i>).&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>7.</b>&nbsp;<f>v.i.</f> <i>Twinkle, blink</i>. <e><m>Ka wheturangitia Matariki, te whetu o te tau e whakamoe mai ra</m> (M. 254).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>8.</b>&nbsp;<f>n.</f> A method of taking the <m>kōkō</m> bird at night. <e><m>Ka haere taua ki te rama i ta taua whakamoe.</m></e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>9.</b>&nbsp;<e>In the expression <m>whakamoe kokota</m>, <i>ambush, ambuscade</i>. <e><m>I te ata ka haere te ope a Ngati Kahungungu, ka whakanohoia te whakamoe kokoti; ka haere atu a Ngati Huri ki roto i nga whakamoe kokoti, ka patua e Ngati Kahungunu</m></e></e> see <m>whakamoe 4</m><br/> <br/><h2>momoe</h2><b>1.</b>&nbsp;<f>a.</f> <i>Of a drowsy habit, somnolent</i>. <e><m>Ha tangata momoe, he tangata mangere, e kore e whiwhi ki te taonga</m> (P.).</e> <e><m>Nana ano i momoe noa; na ka mate tera iwi</m> (T. 62).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;<i>Keeping the eyes closed</i>.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp;<f>v.i.</f> <i>Sleep together</i>. <e><m>Ka haere raua ka tae ki te whare, ka momoe</m> (T. 134).</e><br/> <br/><h2>moemoe</h2><f>a.</f> <i>Sour, acid</i>, i.e., causing one to close the eyes.<br/> <br/><h2>whakamoemoe</h2><b>1.</b>&nbsp;<f>n.</f> A spell for causing an enemy to be overcome by sleep. <e><m>Me te whangawhangai me te whakamoemoe</m> (T. 159).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;<f>v.t.</f> <i>Bring under the influence of a sleep-producing spell</i>. <e><m>Ka rotua te whare e nga wahine ra, ka whakamoemoea kia moe</m> (T. 37).</e><br/>','Moe',NULL,'M');

(Probably only a temporary local substitute when the word <m>wai</m> had been rendered <m>tapu</m>.)<br/> <br/><h2>momote</h2><f>ad.</f> <b>1.</b>&nbsp;<i>Clandestinely</i>. INSERT INTO "dictionary" VALUES(5440,'Mutu','<b>1.</b>&nbsp;<f>a.</f> <i>Brought to an end, left off</i>. <e><m>Mutu kau te kai, kei te korero i te korero o te toa</m> (T. 157).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;<i>Cropped, having the end cut off, truncated, multilated</i>. <e><m>He ringa mutu.</m></e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp;Applied to a year of scarcity. <e><m>E rua tau ruru, e rua tau wehe, e rua tau mutu, e rua tau kai</m> (P. 7).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>4.</b>&nbsp;<i>Come</i> or <i>gone without exception, completed</i>. <e><m>Mutu katoa mai nga tangata ki te kawanatanga, kahore he rerenga.</m></e><e> So <m>tekau mutu</m>, <i>a full ten</i>. </e> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>5.</b>&nbsp;<f>v.t.</f> <i>Cut short, bring to an end</i>. <e><m>Ka tika, a, me mutu i konei</m> (T. 12).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>6.</b>&nbsp;<i>Snare birds</i> with apparatus as below ( see 7 below). <e><m>Ko a taua mea tane hei patu i nga manu, hei taeke, hei wero, hei pae, hei mutu.</m></e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>7.</b>&nbsp;<f>n.</f> <i>Perch carrying a snare</i> for birds. So <m>mutu kaka, mutu kereru</m>, such snares for parrots and pigeons respectively (Tr. xlii, 465.)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>8.</b>&nbsp;Spear thrown towards the advancing enemy by way of challenge and omen.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>9.</b>&nbsp;<e>In the expression <m>mutu o te ate</m>, <i>pit of the stomach</i>.</e> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>10.</b>&nbsp; = <m>Mutuwhenua</m><br/> <br/><h2>mutunga</h2><b>1.</b>&nbsp;<f>n.</f> <i>End, conclusion, terminus</i>. INSERT INTO "dictionary" VALUES(5447,'Na','<f>particle</f> <b>1.</b>&nbsp;Used after words and clauses to indicate position near or connection with the person addressed. <e><m>I ma hea mai koia to koutou na ara i haere mai ai ?</m> (T. 149).</e> <e><m>E pai ana ranei ta tena iwi, tana haka e haka ake na ?</m> (T. 64).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;Used in relative clauses (‖ F.L. § 72, 73). <e><m>Ko ia ano tena i mahue atu na i a koe</m> (T. 59).</e> <e><m>Hei a koe ranei ka kitea ai taua wahi e rapua na e koe</m> (T. 14).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp;As a suffix in the words <m>tena, ena, pena, kona</m>. Of these, <m>tena</m> is sometimes resolved into <m>te</m> and <m>na, te whare na</m> being equivalent to <m>tena whare</m>. Note: In letters and written matter the writer places himself mentally, so to speak, beside the reader, and <m>na</m> is used where <m>nei</m> would be appropriate in conversation.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>4.</b>&nbsp;In animated conversation, where there is no special relation to the person addressed, the force being to add emphasis; sometimes equivalent to the expression, <i>As I was telling you</i>, or, <i>As I say</i>. <e><m>Waiho to ratou purenga nei na hei hunanga mo to ratou puhaehae</m> (T. 135).</e> <e><m>Ko te wai heru tena na, ko te wai whakaata tenei na</m> (T. 54).</e> <e><m>Pera tonu ta raua na mahi</m> (T. 133).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>5.</b>&nbsp;In the expressions <m>na koa, na pea, na ra</m>, etc. <e><m>He tangata tuku taonga ia, a Tuahumahina, ki te iwi ? Na koa, he tangata kaiponu</m> (W. iv, 97).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>6.</b>&nbsp;Adverbially = <m>tena</m><i>There</i>. See also 5, above. see <m>nei (iii)</m><br/>','Na','iii','N');

INSERT INTO "dictionary" VALUES(5554,'Nei','<f>particle</f> <b>1.</b>&nbsp;<when>Used after words and phrases to denote proximity to or connection with the speaker. <e><m>E koro, haria nga toki nei</m> (T. 50).</e> <e><m>Kaua e kai ake i muri nei, kia hoki iho ra ano au</m> (T. 80).</e> <e><m>Kaore nei ano he tangata o muri nei</m> (<i>There is no one left of the present time</i>) (T. 77).</e>   </when> <e> So <m>te po nei</m>, <i>last night</i> </e> see <m>na (iii)</m>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;In some cases the connection with the speaker is not obvious, the force apparently being to indicate continuance of action, or sometimes merely sequence of events. <e><m>Takoto nei, takoto nei, a ao noa te ra</m> (<i>They continued to lie there till the day dawned</i>) (T. 90).</e> <e><m>Ka kai nei, ka kai nei, nawai, nawai a ka mutu</m> (P. 97).</e> <e><m>Ka mate nei a Tupenu … ka haere te rongo</m> (<i>So Tupenu died … and the news of his death spread</i>) (T. 119).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp;In animated narrative, suggesting that the speaker has the events he is telling pictured before him. <e><m>Ka whiti i tetahi awa iti nei</m> (J. xx, 18).</e> <e><m>Ka ahuareka noa iho a raua nei korero ki a raua nei</m> (T. 169).</e>   In this way it is sometimes used redundantly after <m>taua</m> and <m>aua</m>. <e><m>Ka patua taua iwi nei</m> (T. 119).</e> <e><m>Ka hoe mai aua waka nei</m> (T. 69).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>4.</b>&nbsp;In relative clauses (‖ F.L. § 72). <e><m>Te tohunga i tarai nei i to ratou waka</m> (T. 51).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>5.</b>&nbsp;As a suffix, having the same force as in <m>1</m>, above, in the words <m>tenei, enei, penei, konei</m>, of which <m>tenei</m> is sometimes resolved into <m>te</m> and <m>nei, te whare nei</m> being equivalent to <m>tenei whare</m>.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>6.</b>&nbsp;In poetry = <m>tenei</m><i>Here</i>. <e><m>Nei ka noho me he ahi au</m> (M. 99).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>7.</b>&nbsp;Followed by <m>koe</m> or <m>ra</m>, it is used to introduce explanatory sentences. <e><m>Nei koa kua korero te wahine nei ki tana matua</m> (<i>The fact was, this woman had spoken to her father</i>) (T. 194).</e> <e><m>Nei ra ina wera Te Arawa i te ahi a Raumati, ka whakaaroaro te ngakau o nga iwi o Hou</m> (<i>Accordingly when Raumati burned the Arawa, the descendants of Hou had much cogitation</i>) (T. 82).</e> <e><m>Nei ra kia ao ake te ata, tahuri rawa atu ki waho</m> (Pi. 175, 1).</e><br/>','Nei','iii','N');

INSERT INTO "dictionary" VALUES(5602,'No','<b>1.</b>&nbsp;<f>prep.</f> <i>From, of, belonging to</i>. (a) As part to the whole. <e><m>He tikitiki no tona mahunga te harakeke i Otoi?</m> (T. 141).</e>   (b) As inhabitant to country.“No <e><m>hea koe?” “No konei ano”</m> (T. 23).</e> <e><m>No tawhiti tenei tira, no Piako</m> (T. 188).</e>   <m>No hea</m>, interrogatively, is often equivalent to a decided negative. <e><m>No hea e mana, no hea e aha?</m> (<i>It was of no avail whatever</i>) (T. 99).</e>   (c) As parent to child. He matua nona a Paka. (d) As dwelling place to inhabitant. <e><m>Koia ano no Tinirau tenei whare</m> (T. 38).</e> <e><m>Ehara i a koe tenei kainga; noku ano</m> (T. 79).</e>   (e) As clothes to wearer. Ko tera kakahu no nga rangatira anake (Pi. 131, 6). (f) Of quality, disposition, feelings, etc. <e><m>He tupato no nga tohunga</m> (T. 89).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;Of past time. (a) <i>From, from</i> the time <i>of</i>. <e><m>No te mahuetanga o te waiu, katahi ena kai ka kainga e koutou</m> (T. 14).</e>   (b) <i>At, in, on</i>. <e><m>No te ahiahi ano ka haere a Whakatau</m> (T. 61).</e> <e><m>No te tatanga ki te hokinga, katahi ano te ika ka kai ki tana matau</m> (T. 117).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp;<i>On account of, owing to</i>. <e><m>No te tangi ka matau ai a Rehua ko tona teina tenei</m> (P. 175, 2).</e> <e><m>No te katanga a tiwaiwaka i a Mauitikitiki-a-Taranga i kutia ai e Hine-nui-te-po, a mate ana</m> (T. 30).</e><e> <m>No te mea</m>, <i>from the fact that, because</i>. <e><m>Kaore ano i kitea noatia, no te mea i rite ki a ratou te kiri ma</m> (T. 179).</e>  </e> <e> <m>No reira, no kona, no konei</m>, <i>therefore, wherefore</i> <e><m>No reira i haere mai ai a Ngahue ki tenei motu</m> (T. 69).</e> <e><m>No kona hoki te whakataukitanga iho a Toi</m> (T. 63).</e> <e><m>No konei i kauhoetia ai e ia taua moana</m> (T. 164).</e>   </e> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>4.</b>&nbsp;Adverbially. <i>From the time that, at the time that, when</i>. <e><m>A, no ka oria e te hau</m> (T. 101).</e><when>Often when preceded by a incorrectly written <m>ano</m>.</when> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>5.</b>&nbsp;<i>Until</i>. Note: For difference between <m>no</m> and <m>na</m> (F.L. § 22).<br/>','No',NULL,'N');

INSERT INTO "dictionary" VALUES(5670,'Ng','<when>Symbol for the single consonant (a voiced nasal guttural) which bears to <m>k</m> the same relation as <m>m</m> bears to <m>p</m>, and <m>n</m> to <m>t</m>. It is pronounced as <i>ng</i> in “singing”. The European may at first experience a little difficulty in pronouncing this consonant at the beginning of a syllable; to do this the glottis should first be closed, the lips parted, the tongue withdrawn from the palate, the voice passed through the nose (as in <m>m</m> and <m>n</m>), and the glottis opened as the required vowel is formed. Some of the Bay of Plenty tribes substitute <m>n</m> for this consonant; while the Ngaitahu, of the South Island, almost invariably replace it by <m>k</m>. It has not been considered desirable to cumber the dictionary with the enormous number of variant forms due to these dialectic peculiarities.</when> <br/>','Ng',NULL,'Ng');

INSERT INTO "dictionary" VALUES(5701,'Ngahuru','<b>1.</b>&nbsp;<f>num.</f> <i>Ten</i>. This is the old word which occurs in nearly every Polynesian dialect, but has now under European influence been superseded by <m>tekau</m>. Ngahuru ki runga, ngahuru ki raro, ma te paroparo e aki (Ika, 133).&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;<when>With the article <m>te</m>, <i>tenth</i>. <e><m>A penei tonu, tae rawa ki te ngahuru o nga rangi</m> (T. 33).</e>  </when> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp;<f>n.</f> The tenth and eleventh months; the tenth being <m>ngahuru kai paenga</m>, and the eleventh simply <m>ngahuru</m>, or in some districts <m>ngahuru tahi</m>.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>4.</b>&nbsp;<i>Harvest time, autumn</i>. <e><m>Taihoa tatou e haere ki reira, hei te ngahuru; kia rupeke te kai ki te hapoko</m> (T. 189).</e> <e><m>Kaore he takurua, he ngahuru tonu tana</m> (T. 160).</e> <e><m>Koanga tangata tahi, ngahuru puta noa</m> (P.).</e><br/>','Ngahuru',NULL,'Ng');
INSERT INTO "dictionary" VALUES(5702,'Nga.i','<br/><h2>ngti</h2><f>tribal prefix</f> <b>1.</b>&nbsp;The prefix, which means <i>tribe</i> or <i>clan</i>, is equivalent to <m>nga ai, nga ati</m>, as may be seen from the use, chiefly poetical, of such forms as <m>Ati Awa</m>. <e><m>Ko to te Ati Awa rangatira tenei ko Tahuaroa</m> (P. 90).</e>   In the name of a tribe or <m>hapu</m> the final element is generally an ancestral patronymic, <m>as Ngati Tuwharetoa</m>, but sometimes is a word used to commemorate some incident, as <m>Ngati Kumara</m>. The difference in use between <m>ngai</m> and <m>ngati</m> appears to be one of euphony: <m>Ngaitahu, Ngai Te Rangi, Ngai Tai;</m> but there is also a <m>Ngati Tai</m>. Occasionally the prefix is used with <m>mea</m>, to indicate an unidentified tribe. He iwi tautaua a Ngati-mea, he iwi toa a Ngati-mea (<i>One tribe may be cowardly and another brave</i>) ‖ Journ. Anthrop. Inst. xxxii, 183.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;The prefix is sometimes used with a dual pronoun, <m>maua, taua, korua</m>, or a common noun, to indicate a group of persons not necessarily tribal.<e> <m>Ngai-maua, ngati-maua</m>, <i>I and my people</i>, or <i>I and my party</i>. <e><m>Engari ma Ngati-whakaheke anake taua tikanga ki te tango whenua mo ratou</m> (<i>But it is only invaders who adopt such a course as to appropriate land for themselves</i>).</e> </e> see <m>ai (iii)</m>, <m>ati (i)</m><br/>','Ngāi',NULL,'Ng');
