INSERT INTO "dictionary" VALUES(6085,'Pae','<b>1.</b>&nbsp;<f>n.</f> <i>Horizon</i>. <e><m>Ano ko Kopu ka puta ake i te pae</m> (T. 99).</e><e> <m>Pae huakai</m>, <i>horizon</i>. </e> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;<i>Region, direction</i>. <e><m>Kei whea te pae ki toku matua?</m> (T. 136).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp;<i>Horizontal ridges</i> of hills. <e><m>Haere koe ki tawhiti, ki te pae tuatahi, tuarua, tuangahuru</m> (T. 95).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>4.</b>&nbsp;<i>Transverse supports</i> of the <m>karaho</m> (floor) of a canoe. <e><m>Waiho i to tu, waiho i to pae</m> (K. for the Tainui canoe.)</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>5.</b>&nbsp;<i>Any transverse beam</i>. <e><m>Me tauarai mai au ki te pae rakau</m> (M. 336).</e>   So <i>step</i> in a ladder or staircase; rail to which the upright stakes are lashed in the palisade of a pa. Pae kakaho, <i>skirting board</i> round the walls of a <m>whare. Pae whakairi, pae whakaruru</m>, contrivance used by women in childbirth when alone.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>6.</b>&nbsp;<i>Perch, rest</i>. <e><m>He kukupa pae tahi</m> (T. 15).</e> <e><m>Te panganga atu ki te pae miromiro, mate ana te nuinga</m> (T. 96).</e><e> <m>Te pae o te riri</m>, <i>resting place of an <m>ope taua</m> on the march</i>.  </e> <e> <m>Pae-kawau</m>, part of the gateway of a <m>pa</m>. <e><m>Kaore ia i tomo ma raro o te pae-kawau o te pa; i piki ia ma runga i te wawa o te pa.</m></e> </e> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>7.</b>&nbsp;<i>Gums</i>.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>8.</b>&nbsp;<i>Circumference</i>, measured by the <m>maro</m> with the arms extended. He rakau nui, e toru te pae (<i>A large tree measuring three fathoms in circumference</i>). Pae tahi hamama te rakau nei (<i>This tree is over one fathom in circumference</i>).&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>9.</b>&nbsp;<i>Ropes</i> by which a seine net is hauled; called respectively <m>pae runga</m> and <m>pae raro</m>.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>10.</b>&nbsp;<e>In the expression <m>pae-mate</m>, <i>those standing round a corpse, mourners</i>. <e><m>Mo te tangata mate tenei, ka mea te pae-mate ki te tamaiti, kia tangi tonu, kaua e mutumutu</m> (P. 106).</e>  </e> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>11.</b>&nbsp;<i>Number, multitude</i>, of an indefinite number. <e><m>He toko-pae kua mate</m></e> (<i>A number have died</i>) see <m>paepae 5</m>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>12.</b>&nbsp;<f>v.i.</f> <i>Lie across</i>.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>13.</b>&nbsp;<i>Lie on one side</i>.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>14.</b>&nbsp;<i>Be collected together, lie ready for use</i>. <e><m>Pae mai te taonga ki te whare</m> (M. 297).</e> <e><m>E tuwhera ana nga hangi, e pae ana nga rautao, nga wahie, nga kowhatu</m> (T. 90).</e> <e><m>Horahia mai</m> (te korero) kia rongo te rau e pae nei (M. 287).</e> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>15.</b>&nbsp;<i>Be laid to the charge of anyone</i>. Ka pae nei hoki, na korua te tupapaku nei.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>16.</b>&nbsp;<i>Be over, leave a balance</i>, of numbers. E pae tonu ana, kia tae ki te rau kua kore e kiia he pae. (Said in explaining the term paepae, 5, below.)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>17.</b>&nbsp;<i>Be cast ashore, wrecked, stranded</i>. <e><m>E pae ana tera i uta, kua mate</m> (T. 93).</e>   Pass. <m>paea</m>, in the same sense. Ko nga waka tino nui, ki uta paea ai e te tai i te kore tangata hei eke mo runga.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>18.</b>&nbsp;<i>Be thrown down, demolished</i>. <e><m>Pae rawa nga takitaki, me te maihi o te whare</m> (Tr. vii, 49).</e> <e><m>Ka paea te whare, ka tahuna te whare</m> (Tr. vii, 49).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>19.</b>&nbsp;<f>v.t.</f> <i>Surround with a border</i>. <e><m>Paea mai nga parua o te umu kia hoki mai ai te mamaoa ki roto.</m></e> <m>Pae umu</m> = <m>koronae</m>, a band of plaited leaves used to confine food in an oven.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>20.</b>&nbsp;<i>Kill</i> or <i>snare</i> birds. <e><m>Ko a taua mea tane hei patu i nga manu, hei taeki, hei wero, hei pae, hei mutu.</m></e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>21.</b>&nbsp;<i>Measure the circumference</i> of a tree, as see 8 above. <e><m>Ka paea te rakau ra.</m></e><br/> <br/><h2>paenga</h2><f>n.</f> <b>1.</b>&nbsp;<i>Place where anything is laid on one side or across</i>.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;<i>Margin, boundary</i>. <e><m>Ka mahi te awhato hohoni paenga</m> (<i>i.e., eating round the edges of leaves</i>) (P. 38).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp;The outer edge of a <m>kumara</m> plantation. <e><m>Ngahuru kai paenga.</m></e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>4.</b>&nbsp;<i>Place where things are heaped up</i>. <e><m>He paenga rangatira</m> (<i>A place of fallen chiefs</i>) (M. 346).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>5.</b>&nbsp;<i>Site</i> of buildings, etc. <e><m>Kei te paenga rua o Te Raharaha</m></e> see <m>paekiri</m><br/> <br/><h2>whakapae</h2><f>v.t.</f> <b>1.</b>&nbsp;<i>Lay across</i>. <e><m>Me whakapae te rakau nei hei arawhata.</m></e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;<i>Accuse, make an accusation</i>. <e><m>Ko te take i haere mai ai ia, he whakapaenga ki te rua kumara na ona hoa</m> (T. 136).</e> <e><m>Akuanei whakapaea iho na Hotunui i tahae</m> (T. 136).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp;<i>Requite</i> see <m>whakapaepae</m>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>4.</b>&nbsp;<i>Besiege</i>. <e><m>Ka whakapaea taua pa nei e te taua i te po, i te ao, a kihai i taea</m> (T. 182).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>5.</b>&nbsp;<i>Drive ashore, heap up</i>. <e><m>Ko te rimu mau toka … e whakapaea ana ki te one i Rangatira</m> (M. 100).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>6.</b>&nbsp;Used of the manoeuvre of changing the formation of an attacking party from column to line. <e><m>Ka whakapae te riri.</m></e><br/> <br/><h2>papae</h2><f>v.i.</f> <i>Be driven broadside on shore</i>. <e><m>Ka papae te waka, akuanei ka pakaru.</m></e><br/> <br/><h2>paepae</h2><b>1.</b>&nbsp;<f>n.</f> <i>Beam, bar</i>. As (a) the beam across the front of a <i>whare;</i> called also <m>paepae āwhā</m>, <m>paepae kaiāwhā</m>, <m>paepae kainga-āwhā</m>, or <m>paepae roa</m> (J. v, 151). <e><m>Ehara, ka mau ki te paepae o te whatitoka te matau a Maui-tikitiki-o-Taranga</m> (T. 21).</e> <e><m>Hangaia he whare, ko te paepae kai-awha kia rite ki toku kaki te tiketike.</m></e> (b) <i>Threshold, door sill</i>; also termed <m>paepae poto, pae takū</m>, or <m>paepae tapu</m>. <e><m>Ka hoaina e Tamure te paepae o te whare</m> (T. 172).</e> <e><m>Tukua mai, tukua mai, ki te paepae poto a Hou; ka tahi, ka rua, ka toru, ka eke kei te paepae poto a Hou</m> (M. viii).</e>   (c) The horizontal beam of a latrine = <m>paepae hamuti</m>, <m>paepae whakaheke</m>, <m>paepae whakahoro</m><e><m>Ka tae atu ia ki te taha o te paepae ra, na ka hiki atu tetehi o nga waewae ki runga ki te paepae ra</m> (T. 35).</e> <e><m>Ka ngaua e au te paepae hamuti, hai whakaora moku.</m></e> (d) The beam along the edges of the floor mats in a <m>whare</m> (J. v, 151). (e) A bar to support bird snares. <e><m>Na ka rere mai nga kawau, ka mau tonu i te kaki, i te waewae, ka kahakina to paepae manu e nga kawau.</m></e> (f) The bottom bar of a dredge for freshwater crayfish. (g) The wooden spreader for fish-hooks; = <m>paepae roa</m>(h) A piece of wood placed across the path of anyone for the purpose of <m>makutu</m>. The <m>term tō paepae</m> is applied to a woman or man who has been deserted after marriage.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;<i>Dish, open shallow vessel</i>.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp;Upper curl of tattooing on the cheek.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>4.</b>&nbsp;A pattern in wood carving.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>5.</b>&nbsp;An expression used in counting game, etc; the balance aver a complete hundred. <e><m>Kotahi rau, hokorua te paepae</m> (<i>One hundred and forty</i>)</e> see <m>pae (10</m>, <m>15 above)</m>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>6.</b>&nbsp;<f>v.t.</f> <i>Lie in wait for</i>. <e><m>Ka tae te rongo ki a Tuhoe, ka whakatika mai, ka whakaekea e ratau a Te Takatakanga, he taupaepae, ara he whakaeke, he tiaki i te hoariri, e paepae ana i te ope.</m></e> <e><m>Katahi ka tikina ki mua o te ara paepae mai ai.</m></e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>7.</b>&nbsp;<i>Arrange</i> bird snares. <e><m>Ka koromahangatia nga mahanga mo nga kawau, ka paepaetia ki te rakau.</m></e><br/> <br/><h2>whakapaepae</h2> <e>In the expression <m>kai whakapaepae</m>, <i>return present of food</i> from one tribe to another.</e> = <m>kai haukai</m><e><m>Ki whakapaea koutou hei kaihaukai ka mahora ki te aroaro no te atua</m> (M. 417).</e> <br/>','Pae',NULL,'P');

INSERT INTO "dictionary" VALUES(6424,'Papa','<b>1.</b>&nbsp;<f>n.</f> Anything broad, flat, and hard; <i>flat rock, slab, board</i>. <e><m>Oti ake nga papa e rua, ko nga ingoa o nga papa nei na ko Tahitahia, ko Rakerakea. (T. 35)</m></e>  Especially the broad board for closing the doorway or window of a Maori house, so <i>door, shutter</i>. <e><m>Ka toia te papa o tona whare kia tuwhera</m> (T. 172).</e>   <m>Papa reti</m>, board used as a <i>toboggan;</i> the term is also applied to some form of epidemic sickness. He auau no te mate, i poua, e tai, ki te papa-reti (S.). <m>Papa takiri</m>, a piece of wood about 6 in. by ½ in., sometimes used in starting a humming top. <m>Papaara</m>, some part of a canoe.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;<i>Earth floor</i> or <i>site</i> of a native house. <e><m>Ko te papa o te whare wananga e tahia i te tuatahi</m> (W.W. 2).</e>   Hence the modern expression <m>papa kāinga</m>.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp;<i>Bed</i> of a lake. <e><m>Te manu kei taua roto he manapou, e rua tikitiki o te upoko; ko ana tamariki he mea ruku ki te papa o te moana whanau ai.</m></e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>4.</b>&nbsp;A name for the <i>Earth</i>, generally used in relation to <m>Rangi</m>. <e><m>Katahi ka mawehe a Rangi raua ko Papa</m> (T. 4).</e>   Fuller forms of the name are <m>Papa-tu-a-nuku</m> and <m>Papa-tahua-roa</m>. <e><m>Kotahi ano te tupuna o te tangata maori, ko Rangi-nui e tu nei, ko Papatu-a-nuku e takoto nei</m> (T. 3).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>5.</b>&nbsp;Used with a plant name to indicate ground covered with certain vegetation, as <m>papa taraire, papa korari</m>, etc.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>6.</b>&nbsp;<i>Quarrel, ground of dispute</i>. He papa taku ki a ia (<i>I have offended him</i>). Ka riro i a au te papa (<i>I have gained the victory</i>). <e><m>Tuawha ki tona, tuawha ki toku, i a au te papa</m> (T. 200).</e><e>  <m>Papa kore</m>, <i>without grounds, needlessly</i>. <e><m>I mate papa kore te uri o Kaitoa</m> (P. 66).</e>   </e> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>7.</b>&nbsp;The flax foundation of a dogskin or feather cape.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>8.</b>&nbsp;<i>Width, strip</i>, in weaving a floor mat, the joining seams being termed <m>hiki</m> or <m>maurua</m>. I te maurua kotahi e rua papa, i te rua maurua e toru papa.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>9.</b>&nbsp;<i>Mesh</i> of a net.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>10.</b>&nbsp;<i>Shell</i> of crayfish, molluscs, etc. <e><m>Kua tupu te papa o te koura.</m></e><e> <m>Papa tio</m>, <i>oyster shell</i> ; </e> <e> <m>papa pipi</m>, <i>cockle shell</i>, etc.  </e> <e> <m>Papa o te angaanga</m> or <m>papa angaanga</m>, <i>skull</i>.  </e> <e> <m>Papaahu</m>, <i>skull</i>; also some part of a <m>rua kumara</m>. <e><m>Tana papa-ahu ko Papatahia</m> (S. ii, 83).</e>    </e> <e> <m>Papa-āhuahua</m>, <i>shoulder-blade</i>. </e> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>11.</b>&nbsp;<f>a.</f> <i>Lying flat, thrown down</i>. <e><m>Ka tukua iho e Maui te huka kapo; ka uruhia papakia te huka</m> (Tr. vii, 38).</e> <m>Whiri papa</m>, flat platted cord of three strands.<br/> <br/><h2>papanga</h2><f>n.</f> <b>1.</b>&nbsp;<i>Site</i>. Kotahi papanga kainga.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;<i>Layer, course</i>. <e><m>E rua pea papanga o te kareao, e toru ranei, ka oti</m> (T. 154).</e><e> <m>Papanga rua</m> or <m>papa rua</m>, <i>twofold</i>, of fabric. </e> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp;<i>Cause of discord</i>. <e><m>In the passage, Kia tika ki te uru, mo te tai awatea, mo Te Huakiwi; he papanga kei raro, kia rere maramara ki roto Taupo</m> (M. 239).</e>   (Grey interprets as “dead bodies heaped upon one another, i.e., of two parties chief after chief is alternately killed for revenge; any one of them is said to be slain upon a <m>papanga</m>.” But it seems more probable that the word here has the meaning given above.)<br/> <br/><h2>whakapapa</h2><b>1.</b>&nbsp;<f>v.i.</f> <i>Lie flat</i>. <e><m>Whakapapa tonu te manuhiri i te mate</m> (T. 172).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;<i>Go slyly</i> or <i>stealthily</i>. Ka whakapapa mai te tangata ra; he tahae pea.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp;<f>v.t.</f> <i>Lay low, strike down</i>.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>4.</b>&nbsp;<i>Place in layers, lay one upon another</i>.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>5.</b>&nbsp;<i>Recite in proper order</i> genealogies, legends, etc. I haere mai ia ki te whakapapa i nga kauwhau o mua.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>6.</b>&nbsp;<f>n.</f> <i>Genealogical table</i>.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>7.</b>&nbsp;<i>Bush felled for burning;</i> as opposed to <m>hapai tu</m>, timber felled and carried off the ground.<br/> <br/><h2>whakapaparanga</h2><f>n.</f> <b>1.</b>&nbsp;<i>Layer, series of layers</i>.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;<i>Generation</i>.<br/> <br/><h2>pāpapa</h2><f>n.</f> <b>1.</b>&nbsp;<i>Shell</i>, of an egg, crayfish, etc.<br/>','Papa','i','P');

Tahia atu nga parahanga o to tatau kainga.<br/> <br/><h2>parapara</h2><b>1.</b>&nbsp;<f>n.</f> <i>Filth, excrement, offal, spittle, part of the after-birth</i>.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;<i>Remains, scraps</i>. Tae atu ki te parapara maunu, pokepokea iho ki nga toto (Pi. 135, 4).&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp;A place where certain rites were performed. Katahi ka haere ki runga ki te parapara, karakia ana (Pi. 135, 3). <m>Ahi parapara</m> and <m>umu parapara</m> were ovens connected with certain rites, and the rites themselves, in connection with a corpse, tattooing, the first fish caught by a youth, etc. Ka timata te tangata ki te mahi tuna, katahi ano ia ka mahi i tera mahi, ka ka te ahi parapara, ma nga tane anake e kai. <m>Kai parapara</m>, the offence of eating food products from lands which have been made <m>tapu</m>.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>4.</b>&nbsp;<f>a.</f> In expression <m>whitau parapara</m>, flax dyed in mud impregnated with iron. I tukua paraparatia noa iho (<i>It was simply steeped in mud</i>, without having been first soaked in <m>wai hinau</m>).<br/> <br/><h2>paraparahanga</h2><f>n.</f> <i>Fragments, scraps</i> of food, etc.<br/> <br/><h2>whakapara</h2> . A method of propagating kumaras and potatoes. Seed is planted in standing scrub, which is then cut down. When dry enough this was burned. Later the young shoots were transplanted. (Tu.)<br/>','Para','i','P');

Different varieties were known as <m>para kehe</m> (large), <m>para ponaho</m> (small); and <m>para tarare</m> (with a mottled skin).&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;<i>Marattia salicina</i>, a large fern, the root of which was eaten. INSERT INTO "dictionary" VALUES(6868,'Peka','<b>1.</b>&nbsp;<f>n.</f> <i>Branch</i> of a tree, river, etc. He peka titoki e kore e whati (P.). <i>Peka-a-waka</i>, <i>Earina mucronata</i>, an epiphytic orchid.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;<i>Faggot, firewood</i>.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp;<i>Fern root</i>. Probably from the expression, <m>te peka a Haumia</m>, used for fern root.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>4.</b>&nbsp;A flax cape.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>5.</b>&nbsp;<i>Chief</i>. I tu ai te peka i te turanga parekura (S.). Sa. pea, a title of nobility.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>6.</b>&nbsp;In a number of proverbial expressions. <e><m>He peka kai, he peka taonga</m> (P. 24)</e>   (which Grey explains: “A noble present; some provisions and some property, a portion of each”). Patua te peka kainga, ko to peka tangata kia ora (P.). Also given in the form, Ka whakarauoratia ko te peka tangata, ko te peka whenua ka whakamatea iho (P.). Ko te kimi i te peka-a-tama e kore e taea, e kore e kitea; te peka tama, te whanau tamariki, e kore e kitea. The branch idea is obvious enough in the case of <m>tama</m>, and the use seems to have been extended to other words.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>7.</b>&nbsp;<i>Cheek</i>.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>8.</b>&nbsp;<f>v.i.</f> <i>Turn aside</i>. <e><m>Tae noa ki te pekanga, peka tonu hoki ia</m> (J. xx, 19).</e>   In the passive, <i>be turned aside to</i>. Ki te kore au e karanga e kore te kainga e pekaina.<br/> <br/><h2>pekanga</h2><f>n.</f> <i>Branch road</i>. Pekanga na mimi, <i>bastard</i>.<br/> <br/><h2>whakapeka, whakapekapeka</h2><f>v.t.</f> <b>1.</b>&nbsp;<i>Refuse, decline</i>. Kotahi te wahine i noho, kotahi te wahine i whakapekapeka (Tr. vii, 35).&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;<i>Pervert, distort</i>.<e> <m>Korero whakapeka</m>, <i>dark saying</i>. </e> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp;<i>Cause to turn aside</i>. Ma Te Rangitumoana mana e whakapeka, moe rawa ki kona.<br/> <br/><h2>pekapeka</h2><f>n.</f> <b>1.</b>&nbsp;<i>Chalinolobus morio</i> and <i>Mystarops tuberculatus, bats</i>. Pekapeka rere ahiahi, hokioi rere po (P.).&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;A toy windmill made of flax leaf.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp;A small ornament of greenstone. <e><m>Te maha o te heitiki, o te kuru pounamu, o te mako, o te pekapeka, me te poria</m> (T. 153).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>4.</b>&nbsp;A short arm of wood on the two of a fishing line, forming a spreader, to which the tau of the hook was attached.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>5.</b>&nbsp;Lateral arms attached to the tauha roa of an apparatus used at Rotorua for catching crayfish.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>6.</b>&nbsp;A small hooked piece of wood tied to the end of a bird spear to hang it up by when not in use. Kia tae ki runga, katahi ka wetekia te pekapeka. Also the crotch or hook by means of which the mutu bird snare is held on the <m>hiwi</m> while in use ‖ Tr. xlii, 466, 467.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>7.</b>&nbsp;<i>Erechtites quadridentata</i>, a plant.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>8.</b>&nbsp;In the term <m>whiri pekapeka</m>, a flat plat of nine strands.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>9.</b>&nbsp;<i>Cephaloscyllium isabellum, carpet shark</i>.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>10.</b>&nbsp;<i>Starfish</i>.<br/>','Peka',NULL,'P');

INSERT INTO "dictionary" VALUES(7094,'Piro','<b>1.</b>&nbsp;<f>a.</f> <i>Putrid, stinking</i>.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;<i>Extinguished</i>, as a fire or light.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp;<i>Defeated, beaten</i> in a game. Mehemea ka tomo ia ki roto i te wi, ka piro.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>5.</b>&nbsp;<f>n.</f> <i>Foul smell</i>. <e><m>Ata te piro</m> (T. 48).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>6.</b>&nbsp;<i>Scent;</i> not necessarily foul. <e><m>Kua rongo i te piro o Tawhaki raua ko Kariki</m> (T. 47).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>7.</b>&nbsp;<i>Intestines</i>. Ko te tangata nana te niti i rere rawa atu ki tawhiti, i a ia te piro.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>10.</b>&nbsp;<f>v.i.</f> <i>Be apprehended by smell</i>. <e><m>Na ka hongi ki te tonga, kahore i piro mai ki tona ihu</m> (T. 18).</e><br/> <br/><h2>whakapiro</h2><f>v.t.</f> <i>Consider offensive</i> or <i>stinking</i>. <e><m>Muri iho ka whakapiroa e Tawhaki te kotiro</m> (T. 48).</e><br/> <br/><h2>pipiro</h2><f>n.</f> <i>Coprosma foetidissima</i>, a shrub.<br/> <br/><h2>piropiro</h2><b>1.</b>&nbsp;<f>a.</f> <i>Still</i>, as water.<e> <m>Aio piropiro</m>, <i>dead calm</i>. <e><m>Te mohio ki nga tohu o te rangi kei tohutohu i a ratou ki te aio piropiro, me te tupuhi.</m></e> </e> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;<f>n.</f> <i>Petroica macrocephala, yellow-breasted tit</i>. = <m>ngirungiru</m> see <m>pirau</m><br/>','Piro',NULL,'P');

INSERT INTO "dictionary" VALUES(7207,'Poka','<b>1.</b>&nbsp;<f>n.</f> <i>Hole, pit, well</i>. <e><m>Ka rukea nga tupapaku ki waho pukai ai, ka tanumia ki te poka</m> (T. 153).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;<i>Bias</i> in weaving a garment. = <m>tihoi</m>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp;<f>v.t.</f> <i>Make a hole in</i> or <i>through, bore, pierce</i>. <e><m>I haere mai ki te poka i taku puku kia puta taku tamaiti ki waho</m> (J. iii, 100).</e>   Pokaina iho te puku, ka kitea te iwi tupapaku, te pounamu (Pi. 135, 5).&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>4.</b>&nbsp;<i>Cut out, tear out, dig out</i>. <e><m>Te matenga o te tamaiti ra, pokaia ana e Turi te manawa</m> (T. 107).</e> <e><m>Ka pokaia te puku me te ngakau, ka maka ki te moana</m> (J. xx, 17).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>5.</b>&nbsp;<i>Make one''s way, strike out</i> a path. <e><m>I poka tonu mai a Te Arawa ma te taha o Whakaari, pa rawa mai ki Moehau</m> (J. ii, 202).</e>   He ara poka hou tena. So<e> <m>poka pū, poka tata</m>, <i>by a direct route</i> or <i>short cut;</i>  </e> <e> <m>poka te karo</m>, <i>a quick parry</i>. <e><m>Ka kite koe kua tuku mai tona patu ki roto i a koe me tuku ma to ringa maui e poka te karo, kia watea ai to ringa i te patu, ki te whiu i te patu.</m></e> </e> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>6.</b>&nbsp;<i>Adopt a line of conduct</i>, often with the suggestion of strangeness.<e> <m>Poka noa</m>, <i>do anything at random</i> or <i>without authority</i>. </e> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>7.</b>&nbsp;<f>v.i.</f> <i>Appear, come into view</i>.<e> <m>Poka kē</m>, <i>vary, be altered</i>.  </e> <e> <m>Poka noa</m>, <i>appear unusual</i>. <e><m>Me te kiri katoa, i poka noa ake hoki, kihai i rite ki te tangata maori</m> (T. 181).</e>   </e> <br/> <br/><h2>pokapoka</h2><b>1.</b>&nbsp;<f>v.t.</f> <i>Pierce with a number of holes</i>.<e> <m>Mate pokapoka</m>, <i>scrofulous sores</i>. </e> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;<i>Plant in holes, begin to plant</i>. Me pokapoka nga kapana ki te papatua.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp;<i>Do</i> anything <i>irregularly</i>. I pokapokaia te mahi.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>4.</b>&nbsp;<f>a.</f> <i>Irregular, out of order</i>.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>5.</b>&nbsp;<i>At intervals;</i> so, <i>imperfect</i>. No te mea he mohio pokapoka taku mohio ki te whakaheke mai i te po.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>6.</b>&nbsp;<f>n.</f> A hole dug in the ground to mark the spot where a chief was slain.<e><m>He tohu parekura te pokapoka, he mea kari ki te whenua.</m></e> <e><m>Ma nga uri o nga mea i mate e pokapoka i te takotoranga o aua tangata i mate, hai whakaatu ki nga uri.</m></e> <e><m>E kore e pai kia tuwhera te pokapoka ki tahaki, engari me tuwhera tonu kite papa o te huarahi.</m></e><br/>','Poka',NULL,'P');

Ka whakanohoia te mauri ki taua pou.</m></e> </e> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;<i>Pole, stake</i>, used for purposes of incantation. <e><m>Tena te pou ka tu</m> (M. 296).</e><e> <m>Pou aronui, pou tarāwaho</m>, <i>boundary marks</i>. </e> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp;<f>fig.</f> <i>Support, sustenance</i>. <e><m>Me homai e koe tetahi kai hai pou mo tona whaea, kaore ano kia kai.</m></e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>4.</b>&nbsp;<f>fig.</f> <i>Teacher, expert</i>. <e><m>Nga pou o te whare wananga.</m></e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>5.</b>&nbsp;A form of <m>karakia</m> see 15 below, and (Tr. xxxi, 631).&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>6.</b>&nbsp;<e>In the term <m>pou o Hawaiki</m>, <i>Norway rat</i></e> see <m>pouhawaiki</m>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>7.</b>&nbsp;<f>v.t.</f> <i>Stick in, erect</i> a stake, etc. <e><m>Kei te here i a ratou taura ki nga pou i poua ra</m> (T. 152).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>8.</b>&nbsp;<i>Plunge in</i>. <e><m>Te tino rarahutanga ki te hoe; he tino pounga ki te wai i poua ai</m> (T. 171).</e> <e><m>Pounga waihoe ki waho ki te moana</m> (M. 335).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>9.</b>&nbsp;<i>Fix, render immovable</i>, by occult means. <e><m>Ko Tainui ka toia, kaore i paneke … kua poua e tetehi wahine a Hoturoa, e Marama-kikohura</m> (T. 75).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>10.</b>&nbsp;<i>Fasten to a stake</i>, etc. <e><m>Ko te kaha o raro he mea pou ki te pou, here rawa te kaha ki te pou</m> (T. 142).</e>   Poua to tatou waka.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>11.</b>&nbsp;<i>Elevate upon poles</i>. “Apopo ka pou i te kai nei, kia rokohanga mai kua noi ki runga.” <e><m>Ka moe, ka huaki te ata, ka poua te kai</m> (T. 142).</e> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>12.</b>&nbsp;<i>Make a hole</i> with a stake, etc. <e><m>Tae rawa atu ko te poupounga o nga wae rakau</m> (<i>The holes made by the stilts</i>) (M. vi).</e>   Ka poua ki te rakau.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>13.</b>&nbsp;<i>Establish, place</i>. <e><m>Ka u mai taua te ngutu Whenua-kura, poua iho te whare Rangitawhi</m> (M. 89).</e> <e><m>Ko te atua i poua ki runga ki tona kohamo</m> (P. 99).</e> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>14.</b>&nbsp;<i>Appoint</i>. <e><m>Koia te take i poua ai nga pou tiriao ki nga mea katoa hei tiaki</m> (W.W. 15).</e> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>15.</b>&nbsp;<i>Fix</i> knowledge, etc., in mind of a pupil by means of <m>karakia</m>. <e><m>Mehemea kaore e poua ki te karakia, kaore e mau.—Ko Raumati-ninihanga te tangata i mohio ki te pou i te tangata ki te karakia.</m></e> <e><m>Kua poua e au taku wahine ki tenei mahi</m> (Tr. xxxi, 631).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>16.</b>&nbsp;<i>Direct, guide</i>. <e><m>Kei te mohio au ki nga whetu i poua mai ai nga waka, i tika ai te rere i Hawaiki.</m></e><br/> <br/><h2>poupou</h2><b>1.</b>&nbsp;<f>n.</f> <i>Peg, stake, post</i>. <e><m>Tenei taku waka te waiho i te motu hei poupou harore</m> (M. 85).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;Upright slabs forming the solid framework of the walls of a <m>whare</m> (J. v, 147, 8). <e><m>Ko tenei whare he whakairo katoa nga poupou</m> (W.W. 26).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp;<i>Shrouds</i> of a canoe mast.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>4.</b>&nbsp;<i>Support, sustenance</i>. <e><m>Te kai atu koe i a Te Urehakari, i a Waiariki, hei poupou mo roto</m> (M. 215).</e><br/> <br/><h2>5</h2><f>a.</f> <i>Steep, perpendicular, upright</i>. Poupou tonu te pikitanga.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>6.</b>&nbsp;<i>Aloft, on the meridian</i>, of the sun. Ka poupou tonu te ra, te ra tuhoehoe (S.). Ka poupou te ra, ka whakatika mai matou.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>7.</b>&nbsp;<f>v.t.</f> <f>frequentative of <m>pou 6</m>, etc.</f> <br/>','Pou','i','P');

INSERT INTO "dictionary" VALUES(7504,'Pouwaka','<br/><h2>powaka, pouaka</h2><f>n.</f> Post surmounted by a small receptacle for valued possessions. Polack applies the term also to a <m>pataka</m>, and also to a small movable <m>waka</m>, or wooden chest (“Manners and Customs,” i, 209, 210, 229). The word later came to represent the English <i>box</i>; but it must be noted that the Maori transliteration of this is <m>paaka</m>, and, further, that <m>pouaka</m> appears in Lee and Kendall''s vocabulary.<br/>','Pouwaka',NULL,'P');

INSERT INTO "dictionary" VALUES(7533,'Puaa','<f>n.</f> <i>Pig</i>. (obsolete.) Cook relates that the Maoris in conversation mentioned the pig not by description but by name; that they called it <m>booak</m>, which he says was the same as the name he had heard in the South Sea Islands (Voyages, ed. 1793, vol. ii, p. 372). INSERT INTO "dictionary" VALUES(7944,'Puta','<b>1.</b>&nbsp;<f>n.</f> <i>Opening, hole, perforation</i>. <e><m>Ka hu ra i te puta o te reinga</m> (M. 371).</e><e> <m>Puta-auahi</m>, <i>window opening</i>. <e><m>Makere atu ki te whare o tona papa, ka rere ma te putaauahi o te whare.</m></e> </e> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;<i>Vagina</i>.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp;<i>Blister</i>.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>4.</b>&nbsp;Survivor; so widow, widower ‖<m>9</m>, below.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>5.</b>&nbsp;<f>v.i.</f> <i>Move from one place to another, pass on</i>. <e><m>Ka mutu, puta ke he wahi ke, e rima puhi</m> (T. 101).</e> <e><m>Kua puta noa ake</m> (te waka) ki runga (T. 173).</e> <e><m>Heoi kua puta te taura kei raro o te kaki, kua mau</m> (T. 159).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>6.</b>&nbsp;<i>Pass through, in</i>, or <i>out</i>. <e><m>Ko tona ara tenei e puta ake ai</m> (T. 54).</e>   Ka puta te kiore ki roto.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>7.</b>&nbsp;<i>Pass on one side</i>. <e><m>Na Hua te rakau ki a Whiro, ka whakaputaia e Whiro, ka puta te rakau ra</m> (W. ii, 17).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>8.</b>&nbsp;<i>Come, come forth, come out</i>. <e><m>Katahi ia ka puta ki waho o te whare</m> (T. 92).</e>   The context will often necessitate translation by some suitable word. <e><m>Ka puta iho te kupu a te rangatira o te pa, Ko wai koe?”</m> (<i>Was heard</i>) (T. 182).</e> <e><m>Wahia ana te tahā ki runga i nga ringaringa o taua tangata, a kihai i puta te wai mo te koroheke ra</m> (<i>So there was no water for the old man</i>) (T. 182).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>9.</b>&nbsp;<i>Escape, survive</i>. <e><m>Ko Kiorepoto i puta, ko Kioreroa i mate</m> (Tr. vii, 47).</e> <e><m>Maringanui te whakapono kia tere te tae mai, i puta ai he morehu ki te ao.</m></e><when>This sometimes takes the curious form <m>puta te ihu</m>, <i>escape from disaster</i>. <e><m>E ki ana a Pio nana i puta ai te ihu o Tuhoe.</m></e></when> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>10.</b>&nbsp;<i>Appear, come into sight</i>. <e><m>Ka puta mai ano to ratou whaea</m> (T. 12).</e> <e><m>Ka puta mai te aroha o tona whaea ki a Haungaroa</m> (T. 84).</e> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>11.</b>&nbsp;<i>Be born</i>. Generally in the expression puta ki waho. <e><m>Katahi ano Tuhuruhuru ka puta ki waho</m> (T. 36).</e> <e><m>Ka puta tana ki waho ko Pore</m> (T. 114).</e> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>12.</b>&nbsp;<e>In the expression <m>puta kē</m>, <i>be changed</i>. <e><m>Ka ata tutuki mai ki Roto-kakahi, ko te wahi e puta ke ai te ngakau kia haere i te ara ki Tikitapu</m> (T. 157).</e>  </e> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>13.</b>&nbsp;In the adverbial expression <m>puta noa</m>, indicating freedom from limitation, <i>throughout</i>. <e><m>Katahi nga wahine ra ka whakararangitia puta noa ki to ratou waka</m> (<i>Then the women were formed up in line right up to their canoe</i>) (T. 38).</e> <e><m>E puare katoa ana a roto, puta noa ki raro</m> (<i>The whole interior was open right down to the bottom</i>) (T. 13).</e> <e><m>He koanga, tangata tahi; he ngahuru, puta noa</m> (<i>At digging time one man will turn up, at harvest home any number</i>) (P. 19).</e><br/> <br/><h2>putanga</h2><f>n.</f> <b>1.</b>&nbsp;<i>Circumstance, place, etc., of appearance</i>. <e><m>E whakarongo ana raua ki te putanga mai o te hau</m> (T. 93).</e> <e><m>E haere koe, ka titiro ki te putanga mai o te ra</m> (T. 110).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;<i>Gate</i>. <e><m>Kihai i tomo ma te putanga, i piki mai ma runga</m> (T. 85).</e><br/> <br/><h2>whakaputa</h2><b>1.</b>&nbsp;<f>v.t.</f> <i>Cause to come forth</i>. <e><m>Ka wahia i te tungaroa o te whare hei ara whakaputanga mo te tamaiti ki waho, ka whakaputaina</m> (T. 52).</e>   Whakaputa i te ihu, <i>rescue, save</i>. Homai he kai hai whakaputa i te ihu o matou ko aku tamariki see <m>puta 9</m>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;<i>Parry, cause to pass on one side</i> see <m>puta 7</m>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp;<i>Perform ceremonial cleansing from</i><m>tapu</m> contracted from a corpse. <e><m>Kihai i tika te whakaputa a Tuhoro i a ia i tona raweketanga i a Tama-te-kapua</m> (J. ii, 226).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>4.</b>&nbsp;<f>v.i.</f> <i>Begin to come forth</i>. <e><m>Katahi ka whakaputa te tangata whenua ki waho</m> (T. 101).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>5.</b>&nbsp;<i>Boast</i>. Ka kino to mahi whakaputa.<br/> <br/><h2>pūputa</h2><f>n.</f> <i>Blister</i> on the skin.<br/> <br/><h2>putaputa</h2><f>a.</f> <i>Full of holes, pitted</i>.<br/>','Puta','i','P');

The absence of roll led early students to confuse the r sound often with d, and, less frequently, with I. INSERT INTO "dictionary" VALUES(8047,'Rae','<f>n.</f> <b>1.</b>&nbsp;<i>Forehead, temple</i>. <e><m>Ka pa tonu ki te rae o tona matua tane</m> (T. 16).</e>   Ka tu raua he rae atu, he rae mai (<i>They stood facing one another</i>). The word is used curiously in proverbial and epigrammatic sayings, apparently meaning <i>person</i>. Kaore e tika kia haere ko te rae anake (i.e., always take a present with you) (P.). <m>Rae oneone</m> is used in a saying referring to backbiting. Hai te rae oneone koe ka kaha ki te korero, tena kia kite koe he kanohi, he kanohi, kaore koe e kaha.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;<i>Promontory, headland</i>. <e><m>Ra te tai e papaki ki te rae o Taranaki</m> (M. 191).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp;<i>Front edge</i> of a <m>koko-kahawai</m>, or landing net for <m>kahawai</m>.<br/> <br/><h2>raenga</h2><f>n.</f> <i>Point</i> of land.<br/> <br/><h2>whakarae</h2><b>1.</b>&nbsp;<f>v.i.</f> <i>Look</i> anyone <i>in the face</i>. Kihai i pa te ringa o tetahi ki a ia, kihai tetahi i whakarae kau atu.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;<i>Lie exposed</i>. INSERT INTO "dictionary" VALUES(8132,'Rangi','<f>n.</f> <b>1.</b>&nbsp;<i>Sky</i>. He ao te rangi ka uhia (P.). Ma wai e rou ake te whetu o te rangi ka taka kei raro? (P.).&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;<i>Heaven, upper regions, abode of supernatural beings</i>. <e><m>Piki ake Tawhaki i te rangi tuatahi, i te rangi tuarua</m> (M. 226).</e> <e><m>Na katahi ka mohio a Tawhaki no te rangi tenei wahine</m> (T. 48).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp;<i>Weather</i>. Na te rangi kino i kore ai matou e haere.—Hei aha ena ka mauria na e koe i te rangi ataahua, e whiti nei te ra? (Pi. 126, 2). Mahara ra au noku anake te rangi (P).&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>4.</b>&nbsp;<i>Day, period of time</i>. <e><m>Tupato ana nga tuakana, whanga ana i tetahi rangi</m> (T. 95).</e>   <m>Rangi weherua</m>, midnight, <m>Rangi rere rua</m>, twilight.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>5.</b>&nbsp;<i>Stanza, division</i>, or <i>portion of a song</i>. <e><m>Kei puta nga rangi mihi atu ki taku ipo</m> (M. 336).</e>   Rangi rua te haka nei.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>6.</b>&nbsp;<i>Air, tune</i>. <e><m>Ko tona kaitohutohu ko te rangi o te pu a Tutanekai</m> (T. 132).</e>   Sometimes applied to the words sung to an accompaniment. <e><m>He rangi koauau</m> (M. 217).</e> <e><m>He rangi poi</m> (M. 29).</e>   He rangi poi tenei na o matou tupuna.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>7.</b>&nbsp;<i>Tenor, drift</i>, of a speech, etc.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>8.</b>&nbsp;<i>Tower or elevated platform</i> used for purposes of attack or defence of a <m>pa</m>.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>9.</b>&nbsp;A shield of wattled supplejack, etc., impervious to spears, used for approaching the earthworks of a <m>pa</m>.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>10.</b>&nbsp;<i>Head</i> (poetical). <e><m>A titi taku rangi te remu o te toroa</m> (M. 61).</e> <e><m>A pani taku rangi te wai mangotara</m> (M. 164).</e> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>11.</b>&nbsp;<i>Chief</i>. Kaore hoki i korerotia e tona hoa tautohe i te reo ngaro (i.e., <e><m>in an unknown language)</m> (W.M. ix, 33).</e> <e><m>He kaupekapeka ki to Ngati Porou reo</m> (J.ii, 60).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>5.</b>&nbsp;<i>Form of words</i>, as in <i>reo tao</i>, a charm recited over a spear before battle. INSERT INTO "dictionary" VALUES(8413,'Rere','<b>1.</b>&nbsp;<f>v.i.</f> <i>Flow</i>. <e><m>Tena te wai ka rere</m> (T. 86).</e> <e><m>E rere tonu ana te toretore o te kanohi</m> (P. 103).</e><e> <m>He tai rere</m>, <i>a tide which has run well out</i>, as at spring tide. </e> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;<i>Fly</i>. <e><m>Pekapeka rere ahiahi, hokioi rere po</m> (P. 80).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp;<i>Be carried on the wind</i>. <e><m>Ehara, me te huruhuru manu ka rere i te hau</m> (T. 170).</e> <e><m>He puanga kakaho ka rere i te waru</m> (P. 25).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>4.</b>&nbsp;<i>Sail</i>. <e><m>Rere noa atu ana, rere noa atu ana, he waka i tona rerenga</m> (T. 70).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>5.</b>&nbsp;<i>Rush, run, hasten</i>. <e><m>Katahi ia ka rere atu ki te kukume mai i nga puru o te pihanga</m> (T. 13).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>6.</b>&nbsp;<i>Flee, escape</i>. <e><m>Kihai tetehi i rere; ko Manaia anake, ko ia i rere ki te pa</m> (T. 91).</e> <e><m>Nowhea e rere te morehu?</m> (T. 29).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>7.</b>&nbsp;<i>Leap, let oneself go from a height</i>. <e><m>Ka rere iho taua wahine nei ki roto ki te koruarua</m> (T. 13).</e>   Ka whakau mai to ratou waka ki te take o te toka i rere nei te wahine nei (Pi. 133, 11).&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>8.</b>&nbsp;<i>Descend</i>, get down. <e><m>“E oioi te ika, e rere ki te taha katau” … Noho tonu a Kae, kaore hoki i rere ki raro</m> (T. 36).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>9.</b>&nbsp;<i>Fall</i> of rain. <e><m>Ko te rere a te ua koia ano kei te wai e riringi tonu nei</m> (W.M. ix, 54).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>10.</b>&nbsp;<i>Run out</i>, of a line. <e><m>Ka whiua ki te moana, rere tonu, rere tonu, a ka tae ki te tekoteko</m> (T. 21).</e>   No te taenga atu ki te toka ki Matakana ka rere te aho a Kahu.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>11.</b>&nbsp;<i>Rise</i> or <i>set</i>, as heavenly bodies. <e><m>He marama e ka rere ake ana i te pae te ahuatanga</m> (T. 159).</e> <e><m>E to, e te ra, rere whakauru ana ki te rua</m> (M. 145).</e> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>12.</b>&nbsp;<i>Be stretched out</i>. <e><m>Ka rere atu nga ringa ki te pehi i te taha kia totohu</m> (T. 91).</e> <e><m>Katahi ka rere atu te ringaringa o Hine-i-te-iwaiwa ki te hura i te maro o Whakatau</m> (T. 59).</e> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>13.</b>&nbsp;<i>Hang, depend</i>. <e><m>Ko te here ka waiho kia rere ana</m> (T. 147).</e> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>14.</b>&nbsp;<i>Pace to and fro</i> in making a speech.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>15.</b>&nbsp;<i>Come in crowds</i> or <i>numbers, be plentiful</i>. <e><m>Rere noa ana nga tane, e kore rawa i pai te wahine nei</m> (T. 188).</e>   Ka rere te inanga i enei po (S.).&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>16.</b>&nbsp;<i>Be put out, planted</i>. <e><m>He tau pai, ka rere te kumara i a Hepetema; i te putanga kino, ka nekehia ki Oketopa rere ai</m> (W.M. x, 240).</e> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>17.</b>&nbsp;<i>Be born</i>. <e><m>Ka rere ta Tauwhero, ko Hokinga.</m></e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>18.</b>&nbsp;<i>Be uttered</i>. <e><m>Nana anake te kupu i rere mai ki ahau, e kore au e tukua mai</m> (T. 199).</e> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>19.</b>&nbsp;<i>Pass</i> from one thing to another. <e><m>He kino kai, e kore e rere ki te pai tangata; he pai tangata, e rere ki te kino kai</m> (P.).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>20.</b>&nbsp;<i>Be omitted</i>. <e><m>Ka rere tetahi</m> (<i>One has been left out</i>).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>21.</b>&nbsp;<i>Be rejected</i>. <e><m>Hoatu rawa ta taua korero ki a Paoa, rere ana i a ia.</m></e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>22.</b>&nbsp;<i>Come upon</i> one, of feelings, as fear, shame, etc. <e><m>Rere ana te mataku.</m></e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>23.</b>&nbsp;In the phrase <m>rere kē</m>—(a) <i>Be changed, be different</i>. <e><m>Kua rere ke te ahua o te whare</m> (T. 38).</e>   (b) <i>Extraordinary</i>. <e><m>Ka korero i nga korero rere kē noa atu, ka kata noa iho.</m></e><e> <m>Rerenga ketanga</m>, <i>difference</i>. </e> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>24.</b>&nbsp;<f>n.</f> <i>Waterfall</i>. <e><m>I kawea ake au nga rere tangi mai o Te Wai-kohatu</m> (T. 254).</e> <e><m>Katahi ka rawhia reretia te karukaru puru o tana whare</m> (T. 13).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>29.</b>&nbsp;<i>Exactly, quite</i>. <e><m>Tika rere</m> (<i>Perfectly straight</i>).</e><br/> <br/><h2>rerengia</h2><f>pass.</f> <i>Be run upon, over</i>, or <i>after</i>.<br/> <br/><h2>rerenga</h2><f>n.</f> <b>1.</b>&nbsp;<i>Place</i> or <i>circumstances o, leaping, running, etc.</i> <e><m>Te one i Rangaunu, kei te rerenga ki te po</m> (M. 78).</e> <e><m>Hei arataki ki te rerenga wairua ki a Miru</m> (M. 88).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;<i>Voyage, journey</i>. <e><m>Takoto Whangaroa, whaiti kokori, rerenga waka mai nou, e Te Iwikau</m> (M. 375).</e>   Ko nga korero tera o to matou rerenga mai.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp;<i>Setting</i> or <i>rising</i> of sun, etc. <e><m>Te tonga o te ra, te rerenga ki te rua</m> (M. 168).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>4.</b>&nbsp;<i>Place</i> or <i>means of escape</i>. <e><m>Ka wehi hoki; kei whea hoki he rerenga?</m> (T. 180).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>5.</b>&nbsp;<i>Person who has escaped, fugitive, survivor</i>. <e><m>Kahore he rerenga o tenei ope, he mano mano iho ki te mate</m> (T. 93).</e> <e><m>Katahi ka mahara ia kia houhia te rongo, kia kawhakina tetahi rerenga hei morehu</m> (T. 67).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>6.</b>&nbsp;<i>Exception, omission</i>. Mutu katoa mai nga tangata ki te kawana tanga, kahore he rerenga.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>7.</b>&nbsp;<i>Small branches</i> at the extremity of a bough.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>8.</b>&nbsp;<i>Offshoots of a family, distant relatives</i>. Ka puta ia ki ona rerenga.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>9.</b>&nbsp;<i>Planting</i> of <m>kumara</m>, etc. <e><m>Nga whetu tohu o te tau e titiro ai nga tangata matua mo te rerenga o tana kai, o te kumara</m> (W.M. x, 240)</e> see <m>rere (i-16)</m><br/> <br/><h2>whakarere</h2><b>1.</b>&nbsp;<f>v.t.</f> <i>Cast away, reject, discard</i>. <e><m>E pa, e kore koe e whakarere i tou ki raro?</m> (T. 192).</e> <e><m>Ka riri nga hoa ka mea kia whakarerea nga kahu</m> (T. 192).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;<i>Leave, forsake</i>. <e><m>Te haerenga hoki, te whakarerenga iho, ngaro noa</m> (T. 181).</e>   Katahi ka whakarerea e ratou tera wahi.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp;<i>Wield, strike a blow with</i> a weapon. <e><m>Tahi ano te whakarerenga iho o tana mere-mere, ehara kua mate</m> (T. 120).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>4.</b>&nbsp;<f>v.i.</f> <i>Vanish</i>. <e><m>Taria e whakarere ki raro ki te whenua</m> (M. 334).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>5.</b>&nbsp;<f>ad.</f> <i>Suddenly</i>. <e><m>Tukua whakareretia ana te rakau e te iwi ra</m> (W. ii, 161).</e>   Ka puta whakarere mai te hau tonga. <e><m>Kia ea ake ai taku mate whakarere</m> (M. 339).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>6.</b>&nbsp;As an intensive, <i>exceedingly</i>, etc. Te pai whakarere atu o te tamahine nei (Pi. 133, 11). Ahakoa mano tini whakarere te tangata. —Nga mea o tua whakarere (<i>The things of very ancient times</i>).<br/> <br/><h2>rērere, rererere</h2><f>v.i.</f> <i>Run</i>, etc., <i>about</i> from place to place.<br/> <br/><h2>rērere</h2><f>n.</f> A small species of crab.<br/>','Rere','i','R');

INSERT INTO "dictionary" VALUES(8439,'Reti','<b>1.</b>&nbsp;<f>n.</f> <i>Snare</i>.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;<f>v.t.</f> <i>Ensnare</i>.<br/> <br/><h2>rereti</h2><f>n.</f> <i>Blechnum lanceolatum</i>, a fern.<br/>','Reti','i','R');
INSERT INTO "dictionary" VALUES(8440,'Reti','<b>1.</b>&nbsp;<f>n.</f> <i>Canoe</i>. <e><m>Te ai he reti ake hei whiu i a au kia kite hoki au</m> (S. 69).</e> <e><m>Ka utaina ahau ki te reti</m> (S. 51).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;A board with a rod attached at right angles, to which a cord was fastened, by means of which it was towed in the water by a person walking on the shore, so arranged that the board floated on its edge with the rod horizontal. Originally a toy, used in modern times to tow hooks for <m>kahawai</m>. Ka kite i nga tamariki e whakateretere reti ana … ka ki a Tawhaki, “Homai ki a au o korua reti.”&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp;<i>Toboggan board</i>, used on a slide (<m>kaupapa</m>), which was smoothed and wetted ‖ Tr. xxxiv, 61. The board was sometimes called <m>papa reti</m>, a term also applied to <i>epidemic sickness</i>.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>4.</b>&nbsp;A stalk of <m>toetoe</m> (<i>Mariscus ustulatus</i>) or similar plant, sometimes feathered with a leaf of <m>rangiora</m> (<i>Brachyglottis</i>), which was launched in the air from a height as a means of divination. Karakia ana, ka mutu, katahi ka tukuna tana reti … kihai i roa ka tahuri tana reti; ka whakaaro e kore e tika he ara mona (Pi. 135, 3).&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>5.</b>&nbsp;A rite for disabling a foe. Ka pikitia a runga i te reti o to ratou tuakana, ka mate tona ope, ka whakaporangitia e te atua.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>6.</b>&nbsp;A short double-pointed spear, secured by a cord held in the left hand of the thrower. Ko te mate o Tautuporangi, i haere ra te whanau ki te ngaki i te mate, ka tu i te reti, ka ngawha te upoko.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>7.</b>&nbsp;<f>v.t.</f> <i>Convey, carry</i>, as a boat. <e><m>Te ai he kopapa hei reti i a au</m> (M. 18).</e><br/> <br/><h2>retireti</h2><f>n.</f> see <m>reti (ii-3)</m><e><m>He retireti nona i te awa; whakawhitiwhiti ana ki tetahi taha, ki tetahi taha.</m></e> <br/>','Reti','ii','R');

77).</e><e> <m>Ritea</m>, <i>be compared with</i>. </e> <br/> <br/><h2>ritenga</h2><f>n.</f> <b>1.</b>&nbsp;<i>Likeness</i>. <e><m>Pai rawa atu koe i o te tuatahi ritenga kua mahue atu ra</m> (T. tupuna</m> (T. 165).</e> <e><m>Ka pena tonu tana ritenga ki nga tangata e tutaki ana i a ratou</m> (T. 197).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp;<i>Place</i> or <i>thing corresponding, price</i>, etc. <e><m>Ka whakaaroa te wa hei haerenga mona, te ritenga hoki o te wa i munaia atu ra ki ona tangata</m> (T. 170).</e> <e><m>Na katahi ka ruku, ka tae ki te ritenga iho o te waka, ka ringitia te hinu</m> (T. 60).</e><br/> <br/><h2>whakarite</h2> v.t.<b>1.</b>&nbsp;<i>Make like</i>. <e><m>Ka haere hoki ia ki te whakarite i a ia ki te ahua o te kukupa</m> (T. 15).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;<i>Compare, liken</i>. <e><m>Kaore he tangata hei whakarite</m> (T. 61).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp;<i>Put in order, arrange</i>. <e><m>Kia kotahi ta koutou waka e whakarite mo tatou</m> (T. 169).</e>  <e><m>Ka whakaritea nga tangata hei pataritari atu i te ngutu o te ana, ka rite</m> (T. 151).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>4.</b>&nbsp;<m>Balance by an equivalent</m>.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>5.</b>&nbsp;<i>Fulfil, perform</i>. <e><m>Katahi ka whakaritea e ratou te kupu a to ratou rangatira i korero mai ra ki a ratou</m> (T. 170).</e><br/> INSERT INTO "dictionary" VALUES(8615,'Roto','<f>n.</f> (F.L. § 8)<b>1.</b>&nbsp;<i>The inside</i>. Ko roto o te whare, i ki katoa i te tangata.—Tera a waho te kai tahi ra, tera a roto he hahae ke ra (P.).&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;Used in combination with the prepositions <m>ki, i</m>, etc., to form compound prepositions.<e> <m>Ki roto ki</m>, <i>into, in</i>; </e> <e> <m>ki roto i, i roto i, hei roto i</m>, etc., <i>in, within</i>. <e><m>Ka haere raua ko te tuahine ki roto ki te whare</m> (T. 43).</e> <e><m>Tenei te tini o Ngatoro, o Tama, kei roto i te hangi e takoto ana</m> (T. 90).</e> <e><m>Ka takaia ki te takapau, ki te karukaru, ka whakairihia ki roto ki te whare</m> (M. vi).</e>  </e> <when>Sometimes the second preposition is omitted. <e><m>He kai ma roto puku</m> (T. 158).</e>   </when> <e>  <m>I roto i</m>, <i>from within</i>, must sometimes be translated <i>out of</i>. <e><m>Ka whakatika ake i roto i te wai</m> (T. 134)</e> (F.L. § 16.)</e> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp;<i>The midst</i>. <e><m>Ka tu nga tokotoko ki roto ki te otaota</m> (T. 79).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>4.</b>&nbsp;<i>Places inland</i> or <i>up a river</i>. <e><m>Ka kitea ki nga waewae e takoto ana, ahu tonu ki roto</m> (T. 202).</e> <e><m>Ko nga waka hoki o roto e hoe ana ki Ruawehea</m> (T. 144).</e> see <m>rō (i)</m><br/>','Roto','ii','R');

INSERT INTO "dictionary" VALUES(8626,'Rua','<f>n.</f> <b>1.</b>&nbsp;<i>Pit, hole</i>. <e><m>Whakarongo rawa atu ki roto e kanga mai ana, anana! Me he rua kakariki</m> (T. 66).</e> <e><m>Me haere au ki roto ki te rua noho ai</m> (T. 97).</e>   Used of holes dug in connection with rites of witchcraft, etc. <m>Rua torino, rua iti</m>, pits in connection with the <m>tuaahu</m>, the terms being sometimes used as synonymous with <i>witchcraft</i>. Ka kawea ki te rua iti patu ai, ka mate. <m>Rua haeroa</m>, a similar pit in connection with rites for the destruction of enemies. Ka keria te rua haeroa, te rua o te ngana, koia tenei te karakia, “Ei, tena te rua ka keri,” etc. (T. 86) see <m>kanapu</m>, <m>koha</m>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;<i>Store</i> for provisions; in parts of the Bay of Plenty literally a pit in the ground with a narrow entrance, elsewhere generally a shallow excavation with or without low walls, roofed over, and having a small door at one end. <e><m>Ko te rua kumara, ko Marihope</m> (T. 92).</e> <e><m>Ka tapoko taua maia ki roto ki te rua i nga taha huahua</m> (T. 94).</e>   <m>Rua tāhuhu</m>, roofed store for potatoes. <m>Rua koauau</m>, store for <m>kumara</m>. <i>Rua patu</i>, pit for storing provisions (? having thatched roof; see <m>patu</m>). E tika, e whae, taku tonuitanga te rua patu (S.).&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp;<i>Grave</i>. <e><m>Ko nga tupapaku i tanumia ki te rua</m> (T. 155).</e>   <m>Rua totoe</m>, an expression used of a family dying out. Ka poto ratou; he rua totoe i ngaro ai. Ko taua whakananakia ka ngongo i nga uri, a poto iho. Ka whakatakotoria e te tohunga te korohunga ki roto ki te rua, makaa iho te tupapaku. <m>Ruaahuri</m> = <m>urupa</m>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>4.</b>&nbsp;In poetry, <i>abyss</i> into which the heavenly bodies set, and from which they rise, <e><m>Te tonga o te ra, te rerenga ki te rua</m> (M. 168).</e> <e><m>Tera Kaiwaka ka marewa i te rua</m> (M. 407).</e><br/> <br/><h2>whakarua</h2><f>n.</f> <b>1.</b>&nbsp;<i>Hollow, vale, valley</i>. E heke ki raro ra, kai raro te whakarua (S.). <m>Whakarua kawau</m>, a term applied to the hole in which <m>taro</m> is planted when made rather deep see <m>ipurangi</m>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;<i>Feeding ground</i> of birds, particularly of <m>kaka</m>. The term <m>whakarua kaka</m> applies to the feeding ground, and to the birds collected there.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp;<i>North-east sea breeze</i>. <e><m>Puhia mai nei e te hau muri, pa whakarua taku mahuri totara</m> (M. 25).</e>   If moderate, it is termed <m>whakarua mātāriki</m>, if violent, <m>whakarua hikanui</m>.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>4.</b>&nbsp;<i>Waves carried by the north-east wind</i>. Kai tai, kai te whakarua roa (S.). <e><m>Maku e whakatu ki te whakarua roa</m> (M. 335).</e>   <m>Whakarua kopito</m>, a form of ornamental lattice-work, or <m>tukutuku</m>, for the interior decoration of a house.<br/>','Rua','ii','R');

Ka ruru nga whetu (of Pleiades). <e><m>Taonga ruru tonu ki roto i te putea</m> (M. 181).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>8.</b>&nbsp;<i>Inclement</i>. <e><m>E rua tau ruru</m> (<i>Two years of wind and storm</i>) (M. 323).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>9.</b>&nbsp;<f>n.</f> <i>Knot</i>. <e><m>Kapa ianei ko te ruru i wetekina</m> (M. 176).</e> <e><m>Runa mai ra te ruru i a Rongo</m> (M. 334).</e>   <m>Ruru-aho-tuwhere</m>, a knot for securing the door of a house ‖ J. v, 148.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>10.</b>&nbsp;<i>Lashing</i> for securing the <m>rauawa</m> of a canoe.<br/> <br/><h2>whakaruru</h2><b>1.</b>&nbsp;<f>a.</f> <i>Affording shelter, sheltering</i>. <e><m>Ka whati nga rata whakaruru o runga</m> (M. 25).</e> <e><m>Ko te pa whakaruru hau o te mara</m> (M. 363).</e> <e><m>Aku manu whakaruru ki te nohoanga nui</m> (M. cvii).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;<f>n.</f> <i>Shelter, screen</i>. <e><m>Nga whakaruru hau o tini raua ko mano</m> (M. 351).</e> <e><m>Taku whakaruru totara</m> (M. 198).</e> In this and preceding paragraph the terms are used figuratively of a <i>chief</i>.<e> <m>Whakaruru-hau</m>, <i>the Magellan Clouds</i>. <e><m>Ka wehe atu era tama a Rangi ki runga, i a Whaitiri, i a Tautoru, i a Matariki, i a Te Whakaruru-hau.</m></e> </e> <br/> <br/><h2>rūruru</h2><b>1.</b>&nbsp;<f>v.t.</f> <i>Tie up, enclose</i>, <e><m>Maku e rururu ki te putea</m> (M.M. 196).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;<f>n.</f> <i>Bundle</i>. Tangia te riu o te waka.—Tangia te wai o to waha (<i>Bail out your mouth</i>, i.e., <i>cease talking</i>).&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>6.</b>&nbsp;<i>Cut</i>. E haere ana ahau ki te ta toetoe mo toku whare.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>7.</b>&nbsp;<i>Tattoo</i>. <e><m>Takoto ra, e hine, kia taia o ngutu, to kauae, kia pai ai koe</m> (M. 58).</e>   I taia to moko ki te aha ? (P.).&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>8.</b>&nbsp;<i>Sprinkle</i> by means of a branch or bunch of leaves dipped in water.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>9.</b>&nbsp;<i>Paint</i>. <e><m>Ka wehi taua iwi ki ona kanohi, ano i taia ki te takou te whero</m> (T. 16).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>10.</b>&nbsp;<i>Carve, fashion</i>. He pounamu, he aurei, i hoatu e te tangata ki te tohunga kia taia, ara kia hangā hei matau.—Katahi ka taia te matau ra, whakapiri rawa ki te paua.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>11.</b>&nbsp;<i>Overcome</i>. <e><m>Ka taia e te moe</m> (W. i, 115).</e> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>12.</b>&nbsp;<i>Lay, allay</i>. <e><m>He ta kopito</m> (M. 44).</e> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>13.</b>&nbsp;<f>n.</f> <i>Maul, mallet</i>.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>14.</b>&nbsp;<i>Whip</i> for a top.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>15.</b>&nbsp;<i>Scoop</i> for bailing a canoe. = <m>tatā</m>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>16.</b>&nbsp;Stroke with a <m>taiaha</m>.<br/> <br/><h2>tāinga</h2><f>n.</f> <i>Place for bailing</i> in a canoe. <e><m>Ko au nei te whanatu hei te tainga riu</m> (M. 252).</e> <e><m>Ka ngaro katoa te ihu, tango ake ki te tainga wai</m> (M. ix).</e>   Sometimes in the form <m>tāingāwai</m>. <e><m>Ka taea te taingawai o te ihu, tango atu ki te tangawai o waenga</m> (T. 72).</e><br/> <br/><h2>tānga</h2><f>n.</f> <b>1.</b>&nbsp;<i>Circumstance, time</i>, or place of <i>dashing, striking</i>, etc => 1–12, above. <e><m>Kei hea te wahi tanga wahie?—He whakawai tanga moko</m> (M. 57).</e>   <m>Tānga kakariki</m>, a perch or stand so arranged that parakeets settling on it could be killed by a blow from a stick. <m>Tānga ika</m>, (a) The slaying of something either as an offering for, or subsequently dedicated to, an <m>atua</m>. <e><m>E ta, me patu e taua te oi hei tanga ika ma taua</m> (W. iii, 39).</e> <e><m>Kia tae atu au ki te kawe i te hau o tenei tanga ika</m> (T. 22).</e>   (b) The custom of presenting to the relatives of a warrior the property of one whom he has slain in battle.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;The place where a seine is brought to land. Tawewetia te tanga mo te kupenga.<br/> <br/><h2>tātā</h2><f>v.t.</f> <b>1.</b>&nbsp;<i>Dash down, beat down</i>. <e><m>He kawatawata tata moana te koangiangi</m> (J. xx, 17).</e><e> <m>Ua tātā</m>, <i>very heavy rain</i>. </e> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;<i>Break in pieces</i> by dashing on the ground. Tatakia te rakau na hei wahie ma taua.—Tatakina a tatou wahie kia matariki. <m>Tātā wahie</m> is now applied to cutting firewood with an axe.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp;<i>Strike repeatedly</i>. <e><m>Kua uru ia ki roto ki nga matua a tera, tata haere ai, takirua, takitoru ki roto i te rapa o tona taiaha</m> (J. xx, 23).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>4.</b>&nbsp;<i>Oppose, contradict</i>. E pa, he kupu tata tau kupu.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>5.</b>&nbsp;<i>Hew out</i>. INSERT INTO "dictionary" VALUES(8701,'Ta.','<f>definitive particle</f> <when>Used with pronouns, nouns, and proper names to indicate possession.</when> <b>1.</b>&nbsp;To form a simple possessive, <i>the</i> … <i>of</i> = te … a. <e><m>Ka wehi noa ake te matua a Hatupatu … tena ko ta Hatupatu matua kotahi, he maha nga rangatira</m> (T. 101).</e> <e><m>Ko ta korua mokai he ika haehae kupenga</m> (T. 200).</e> <e><m>He aha ta te tangata haere pononga?</m> (<i>What are the means of a man who is travelling</i>?) (T. 196).</e> <e><m>Ko ta namata kai nui tenei he kuri</m> (T. 139).</e> <e><m>Kia hohoro ta ratou haere</m> (T. 147).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;To supply the want of the verb <i>have</i>, in which case the object generally has the indefinite article he. <e><m>He putorino ta Tutanekai, he koauau ta Tiki</m> (T. 130).</e> <e><m>He tangi ta te tamaiti, he whakama ta te kaumatua</m> (P. 827).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp;Elliptically, either to obviate the repetivtion of the noun, or implying the reference to intention, inclination, saying, etc. <e><m>Ka hutia ake e Irawaru tana aho, akuanei ka arau ki ta Maui</m> (T. 25).</e> <e><m>Kihai i hamumu te waha o nga tuakana no te mea kua he ta ratou</m> (T. 200).</e>   Ka mea atu Te Hikaka, “Maoa tonu.” <e><m>Ta Kapua, “Hua atu, kai mata, whiwhia; maoa, riro ke”</m> (P. 104).</e> <e><m>Ka hei ta raua; apopo au kite iho ana i a raua</m> (T. 200).</e>   Hei reira ka kotikoti ai te ika nei, a ka riro pai ta tera, ta tenei na, ta tera ra (i.e., <e><m><i>and each will receive his share</i>)</m> (T. 22).</e>   Also in reciting genealogies, <m>tama</m> being understood. <e><m>Ta Kihi ko Rangiaho, ta Rangiaho ko Te Heuheu</m> (M. Ixvii).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>4.</b>&nbsp;<e>In the expression <m>ta te mea</m>, <i>the fact being that, because</i>. <e><m>Ka mea ia ki tona matua whangai kia whakaaro ki ana kupu i mea atu ra ki a ia, ta te mea kua pa ia ki a Hinemoa</m> (T. 131).</e> <e><m>Ka tupu te whakaaro i a Tawhirimatea kia tahuri mai ia ki te whawhai ki ona tuakana mo te wehewehenga i o ratou matua, ta te mea kaore ia i whakaae kia wehea raua</m> (T. 4).</e>  </e> Note: With the singular personal pronouns ta combines with the pronominal suffixes, and forms the words <m>tāku, tāu, tāna</m>, which are treated separately. The construction te … a may be used indifferently for <m>ta</m>, as in the example under <m>1</m>, above, except with personal pronouns. For the difference between <m>tā</m> and <m>tō</m> (x), see <m>a (ii)</m>, <m>o (iii)</m>(F.L. § 22.)The pl. of <m>tā</m> is <m>ā</m> see <m>ā (iii)</m><br/>','Tā','viii','T');

INSERT INTO "dictionary" VALUES(8711,'Tae','<b>1.</b>&nbsp;<f>v.i.</f> <i>Arrive, come, go</i>. <e><m>Kihai i taro kua tae mai; tae kau mai ano kua titiro ia</m> (T. 35).</e> <e><m>Tera pea e tae mai ki konei</m> (T. 188).</e> <e><m>Ka rongo a Maui i te ika ka tae ki tana</m> (T. 25).</e> <e><m>Kua tae atu te kaitiki atu i tetehi ngohi mana</m> (T. 141).</e> <e><m>Na nga moe kino kihai ratou i tae i te wehi</m> (T. 201).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;<f>v.t.</f> <i>Arrive at, reach</i>. <e><m>Ka hoe te tuakana, ka tae ki uta</m> (M.M. 185).</e> <e><m>“E kore ranei au e tae?” “E kore koe e tae; ko nga rangi tenei i roherohea e Tane”</m> (T. 32).</e> <e><m>Ka taea te taingawai o te ihu</m> (T. 72).</e> <e><m>Ko te piro tupa-paku kua tae mai ki o raua ihu</m> (T. 176).</e><br/> <br/><h2>3</h2> . <i>Extend to</i>, of space or time; sometimes used impersonally, and equivalent to <i>as far as, until</i>. E korero tito ana, no ratou te whenua tae mai ki Rangitaiki. <e><m>Na, kia rongo mai koe; kaore rawa a Te Urewera whenua i tae mai ki konei</m> (W.M. x, 178).</e> <e><m>Ka tupato ki te mahi maminga tonu a taua wahine ia po, ia po, a tae noa ki tetehi atu po</m> (T. 12).</e>   Ka noho ki Piako taea noatia te ngahuru. <e><m>Ka tae ki te ngahuru ka mānu te teretere a Paoa</m> (T. 189).</e> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>4.</b>&nbsp;<i>Touch</i>, of feelings. <e><m>Ka mahara te wahine ra, “E, kua mate!” Ka tae te puaroha ki a ia</m> (M.M. 186).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>5.</b>&nbsp;<i>Amount to</i>, of numbers. <e><m>I tae ki te toru mano nga tangata ki te whakaaro iho</m> (W.M. ix, 25).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>6.</b>&nbsp;<i>Equal</i>. <e><m>E kore tau e tae ki taku</m> (W. iv, 180).</e>   Kahore he tangata e taea ai a Te Horo te oho.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>7.</b>&nbsp;<i>Proceed to</i>; the object being introduced by <m>ki</m>, and the ensuing action being generally indicated by a passive verb. <e><m>Ka tae a Tawhaki ki nge ona, whakarerea ake</m> (<i>Tawhaki proceeded to discard his clothes</i>) (T. 52).</e>   Tae atu te wahine ra ki tona ihu, motokia ake (<i>The woman proceeded to punch her nose</i>) (Pi. 135, 4). <e><m>Ka tae a Kae ki nga paua, ka whakapiria ki nga kanohi</m> (T. 37).</e> <e><m>Ka tae te tangata ra ki tana taurekareka, ka hoatu hei utu mo te ruahine ra</m> (T. 49).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>8.</b>&nbsp;In the passive, <i>be effected, be accomplished</i>. <e><m>Ka taea e au tenei, ka taea hoki e au tera atu aianei</m> (T. 19).</e> <e><m>To noa, to noa, te taea</m> (T. 76).</e> <e><m>E taea hoki te aha?</m> (<i>What could they do?</i>) (T. 200).</e>   Often with an infinitive to denote the character of the action. <e><m>E kore e taea te whai</m> (T. 144).</e> <e><m>Kihai i taea te korikori</m> (T. 143).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>9.</b>&nbsp;<i>Be overcome, be taken</i>. <e><m>Ka whakapaea taua pa nei e te taua i te po, i te ao, a kihai i taea</m> (T. 182).</e>   Ka taea taku raru.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>10.</b>&nbsp;With a negative, expressing inability or impossibility. <e><m>Te taea te whakamanawanui</m> (<i>It could not be borne</i>) (T. 82).</e><br/> <br/><h2>taeatanga</h2><f>n.</f> <i>Sack, capture</i>. <e><m>I nohoia tonutia hoki taua pa e Ngati Maru i muri iho o te horonga, ara o te taeatanga e te taua a Tauru ma</m> (W. v, 122).</e><br/> <br/><h2>whakatae</h2><f>v.t.</f> <i>Cause to come about</i>. <e><m>Na te ngakau koi hotahota he whakataenga koronga</m> (M. 287).</e><br/> <br/><h2>whakataetae</h2><f>v.t.</f> <i>Try strength, contend</i>. <e><m>Ka mea a Tamure kia whakataetae ia ki a Kiki</m> (T. 172).</e><br/>','Tae','i','T');

also a rope or cord used for the same purpose. <e><m>Ka oti te whakawene, ka hereherea ki runga ki te tahu.</m></e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp;A rod placed across the back of a kite to keep the wings extended. <e><m>Ka kuhua te tahu o te taratahi, tutuki noa ki tetahi parirau, ki tetahi.</m></e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>4.</b>&nbsp;Any similar rod used as a <i>stiffener</i>. <e><m>Ka herea tetahi pito o te tahu o nga kaha ki tetahi turuturu.</m></e><e> <m>Tauhu roa</m>, a beam carrying side arms (<m>pekapeka</m>), to which bunches of fern were attached, and the whole submerged for taking crayfish at Rotorua. </e> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>5.</b>&nbsp;The rod laid along the mound of the <m>tuaahu</m> in certain ceremonies.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>6.</b>&nbsp;The first weft in weaving a garment.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>7.</b>&nbsp;<i>Direct line of ancestry</i>. <e><m>Ko enei tangata, ko Tuamatua raua ko Uruika, ko raua te tahu nui o Te Hekengarangi, te tino kawai ariki: ko raua te tahu iho, tae iho ki nga uri.</m></e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>8.</b>&nbsp;<i>Eldest son of the eldest branch</i> of a family.<e> <m>Tahuhu haere</m>, <i>trace descent in a direct line</i>. <e><m>E tahuhu haere nei ano toku ingoa ki toku tupuna, ki a Manaia</m> (T. 123).</e>   </e> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>9.</b>&nbsp;<f>v.t.</f> <i>Arrange snares on a horizontal rod or cord</i>. <e><m>Ka tae te kuia ra ki nga ti, a ka kopiko; INSERT INTO "dictionary" VALUES(8828,'Tai','<br/><h2>taitai</h2><b>1.</b>&nbsp;<f>v.t.</f> <i>Dash, strike</i>. <e><m>I tukitukia ai koe, i taitaia ai nga haupapa kohatu i waho o Totorewa</m> (M. 225).</e> <e><m>To kiri i taitaia ki te ahi manuka</m> (M. 347).</e> <e><m>Ahua, e te iwi, te rangahau o te hoe, a taitaia te ia ki Mahurangi</m> (M. 161).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;<i>Knock, brush</i>. Ka taitaia nga kai ki te rau rakau, kia kore atu te pānga wera.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp;Perform certain ceremonies to remove <m>tapu</m>, etc.; the ceremony apparently originally involving striking the object with a twig. Katahi ka taitai, ka tu te tohunga, me te rakau i tona ringa, ka karakia, “Taitai, taitai, taitai, te kau nunui, te kau roroa.” Ko te karakia taitai tenei.—Katahi ka taitaia, kia, ora ai nga kai, nga kakano, nga manu. <e><m>Ka taitaia te waka</m> (T. 112).</e>   In the case of a canoe the ceremony was accompanied with the slaughter of a slave; hence, “He taitainga waka koe noku” is equivalent to “<i>You are my slave</i>.'' <i>Ahi taitai</i>, a sacred fire in connection with various rites. Ka tahuna te ahi taitai, ka hoatu te rau huka o te ti.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>4.</b>&nbsp;<f>n.</f> <i>Firstfruits</i>, of birds, fish, etc.; used in certain sacred rites at the <m>ahi taitai</m>.<br/>','Tai','iv','T');

used chiefly in measuring houses.<e><m>Ko te roa o te whare, kotahi kumi ma ono; ko te rahi, e iwa takoto</m> (Pi. 135, 5).</e><br/> <br/><h2>takotoranga</h2><f>n.</f> <i>Receptacle, position, site</i>.<br/> <br/><h2>whakatakoto</h2><b>1.</b>&nbsp;<f>v.t.</f> <i>Lay down</i>. <e><m>Ka whakatakotoria tana taiaha</m> (T. 55).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;<i>Plan, determine</i>. <e><m>I whakatakotoria ano ki te korero, e pa ma</m> (M. 429).</e><e> So <m>whakatakoto whakaaro</m>, <i>decide, determine</i>. </e> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp;<i>Give direction, order</i>. INSERT INTO "dictionary" VALUES(9380,'Tapu','<b>1.</b>&nbsp;<f>a.</f> <i>Under religious</i> or <i>superstitious restriction;</i> a condition affecting persons, places, and things, and arising from innumerable causes. Anyone violating <m>tapu</m> contracted a <m>hara</m>, and was certain to be overtaken by calamity. As a rule, elaborate ceremonies were necessary to remove <m>tapu</m> and make anything <m>noa</m>. <e><m>Ka tapu hoki te kainga i a Tawhaki</m> (T. 51).</e> <e><m>I tapu ai te tane, i waiho nga wahine hei mea noa, hei waha kai</m> (M. lxxviii).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;<i>Beyond one''s power, inaccessible</i>. <e><m>Toko-wha ona hoa i kainga katoatia e ia; kotahi i tapu, ko Tawhiri</m> (T. 7).</e> <e><m>Ko te tiketike o nga maunga hei wahawahanga mo nga koiwi, i tapu ai Rotorua</m> (M. 48).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp;<i>Sacred</i>. (mod.)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>4.</b>&nbsp;<f>n.</f> <i>Ceremonial restriction, quality or condition of being subject to such restriction</i>. <e><m>Tena te tapu no Tu</m> (M. 334).</e> <e><m>No reira i nui ake ai te tapu o nga tane i nga wahine</m> (M. Kia tau te mauri o te kai ki raro (P.).&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>6.</b>&nbsp;<i>Come over, supervene</i>, of feelings. <e><m>Heoi ka tau te pouri ki te tohunga</m> (T. 128).</e> <e><m>Ko te tatangi o te poria; a, tau ana te wehi</m> (T. 156).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>7.</b>&nbsp;<i>Lie steeping in water</i>. Ko etahi (aruhe) ka kawea ki te wai, tau atu, tau atu; ma te wahine e patu.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>8.</b>&nbsp;<i>Be suitable, be comely, befit</i>. <e><m>Katahi ano koe ka tau, kia pena ki to tuakana aianei, ka hinga, ka mate</m> (M.M. 187).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>9.</b>&nbsp;<i>Be possible</i>. <e><m>Ka tau te ara ki te moana, e ra</m> (M. 334).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>10.</b>&nbsp;<i>Be able</i>. <e><m>E kore koe e tau hei whai ake mo te Taki-aho-Kariki</m> (M. 412).</e> <br/> <br/><h2>tauranga, taunga</h2><f>n.</f> <i>Resting place, anchorage</i> for canoes, <i>fishing ground</i>. <e><m>Ka korero ia ki ona tangata kia haere ki te tauranga o nga waka, ki reira whanga mai ai i a raua</m> (T. 169).</e> <e><m>Katahi ka hoe ratou, ka tae ki nga tauranga i tau ai nga waka i mua</m> (T. 20).</e> <e><m>I te ata ka eke ia ki tetahi o nga waka ka tae ki te taunga</m> (J. xx, 17).</e>   The expression <m>tauranga ika</m> is sometimes used. <e><m>He whakatete ki nga tauranga ika, ki nga tauranga mango i waho o Puponga</m> (W. iv, 112).</e><br/> <br/><h2>whakatau</h2><f>v.t.</f> <b>1.</b>&nbsp;<i>Cause to alight</i>, etc.<e> <m>Titiro whakatau</m>, <i>look intently</i>. <e><m>Katahi ano taua tangata ka titiro whakatau atu</m> (T. 61).</e> </e> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;<i>Attempt, try one''s hand at</i>. <e><m>Katahi ano tona papa ka whakatau epa ake</m> (T. 16).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp;<i>Have recourse to</i>. <e><m>Whakatau noa iho ia ki te noho</m> (T. 32).</e> <e><m>Katahi ano ia ka whakatau penei, “Moi !”</m> (T. 27).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>4.</b>&nbsp;<i>Imitate</i>. <e><m>Ko wai tau e whakatau nei?</m></e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>5.</b>&nbsp;<i>Feign, make believe, simulate</i>. Ka whakatau ki te kereru, ka rere. <e><m>Ka whakatauria e ia ki te kereru</m> (W. ii, 66).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>6.</b>&nbsp;<i>Go to meet, visit</i>. <e><m>Ka ki ake ki ana tamariki kia hoki atu ki Maketu ki te whakatau i ana whanaunga</m> (T. 78).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>7.</b>&nbsp;<i>Search, examine</i>. <e><m>Kua puta ke pea ia i tawhiti: katahi ia ka mea kia haere ia ki te whakatau</m> (T. 184).</e>   Ka haere mai ki te whakatau i reira.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>8.</b>&nbsp;<i>Adorn, make comely</i>. <e><m>To kiri i whakataua ki te renga horu</m> (M. 158).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>9.</b>&nbsp;<i>Put on as an ornament</i>. <e><m>Whakataua mai te awe o te toroa</m> (M. 46).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>10.</b>&nbsp;<i>Prepare, make ready</i>. Ka whakatau i tona kanohi ki te pungarehu (Tr. vii, 48).&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>11.</b>&nbsp;<i>Address in formal speech, announce a formal decision, make a formal proposition</i>. Heoi ano te putake o ta matou korero, he whakatau i a koe kia noho. Whakatau oha, <i>make a dying speech</i>. <m>Whakatau-ki</m> (generally written as one word), (a) <i>Exclaim, say with emphasis</i>. Katahi ia ka whakatauki atu, “Nana koutou, e whae ma,” etc. (T. 20). <e><m>Ka whakatauki atu taua ruruhi ra ki a Te Huhuti, “E, e tia tonu tou humarie!”</m> (T. 164).</e>   Ka whakatauki, “He aha tenei kai ?” (b) <i>Utter a proverb</i>, use for purpose of a proverb. Ko tenei manu ko te weka, e whakataukitia ana. (c) <i>Saying, proverb, aphorism</i>. <e><m>Ka mea a Paoa, “Rahirahi tonu, kaua e matotoru”; a, mau tonu iho tenei whakatauki i a Ngati Paoa</m> (T. 191).</e>   The form <m>whakatauāki</m> is also used in senses (b) and (c). <e><m>Ka whakatauakitia, “E ! koia ano i mao ai; kaore, kua wheturangitia te marama”</m> (W.M. viii, 110).</e> <br/> <br/><h2>tatau</h2><f>v.t.</f> <i>Settle down upon</i>. <e><m>Tatau atu ana te po i a koe, whiti ana te ra i a au nei; tatau atu ana te kohu i a koe, whiti ana te ra i a au nei</m> (M. 132).</e><br/>','Tau','v','T');

Ki te mea he kiore te hinu i ro taha, ka taua ano te kiore.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp;<f>v.i.</f> <i>Bark</i>. <e><m>Katahi ka tau te kuri nei</m> (T. 120).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>4.</b>&nbsp;<f>n.</f> <i>Song</i> see <m>1 above</m>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>5.</b>&nbsp;<i>Noise, report</i>.<br/> <br/><h2>whakatau</h2><f>v.i.</f> <i>Bark</i>. Mate atu he tete kura, whakaete mai he tete kura (P.). (The figure is probably connected with the previous meaning, or the following.)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp; <i>Todea superba</i>, a fern. INSERT INTO "dictionary" VALUES(10047,'Tekau','<f>num.</f> <i>Ten, tenth</i>. <e><m>Tekau nga taro e tihi ana i tona aroaro</m> (T. 49).</e> <e><m>Ka waru, ka iwa; na kua riro mai te tekau i a Tawhaki</m> (T. 49).</e> Note: The use of <m>tekau</m> for <i>ten</i> is the result of intercourse with Europeans. Before this intercourse <m>tekau</m> was generally used for <i>twenty</i>, and <i>ten</i> was designated by <m>ngahuru</m>, the regular Polynesian word. The numerals are so given by Savage in 1807. Nicholas, who visited New Zealand in 1814, gives for <i>ten</i> <m>ngahuru</m>, and for <i>twenty</i> <m>tekau ma ngahuru</m>; this one would expect to indicate <i>thirty</i>, and it probably did, as he gives <m>ka rua tekau</m>, <i>forty</i>. By 1820, according to Kendall, the modern use of <m>tekau</m>, <i>ten</i>, would appear to have become established. For some purposes—e.g., the counting of fish—<m>takau</m> in some districts indicated <i>eleven</i>. Ka iwa, ka ngahuru, ka tekau. This seems to support the suggestion that <m>te kau</m> was <i>the tally</i>. A thorough investigation of the ancient numeration is given by Best, Tr. xxxix, 150 <i>et seq</i>.<br/>','Tekau',NULL,'T');

In this use <m>atu</m> is sometimes added. <e><m>Ka taea e au tenei, ka taea hold e au tera atu aianei</m> (T. 19).</e><e> <m>Tera tau</m>, <i>last year</i>, or <i>next year</i>, according to the context. </e> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp;Repeated to give distributive force. <e><m>Ara kei tera whenua, kei tera whenua e haere ana ki te kai taonga</m> (P. 105).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>4.</b>&nbsp;Often used for the 3rd pers. pron. <i>He, she</i>. <e><m>Ka ki mai tera, “Kei te ata tonu”</m> (T. 90).</e> <e><m>Ka po hoki, ka hui tera ki roto ki te whare i noho ai a Paoa</m> (T. 199).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>5.</b>&nbsp;<f>ad.</f> <i>Yonder</i>. <e><m>Tera a Takakopiri te haere mai ra</m> (T. 146).</e> <e><m>Tera Kaiwaka ka marewa i te pae</m> (M. 407).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>6.</b>&nbsp;<i>There</i>, indefinite, <e><m>Tera ano tetahi pa nui o namata</m> (T. 166).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>7.</b>&nbsp;<i>Then</i>. <e><m>Te taenga ki te one i Tirau, tera ka kitea mai e nga toro</m> (J. xx, 22).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>8.</b>&nbsp;With the future, to give emphasis. <e><m>Tera ranei au e whakamahia?</m> (<i>Shall I really be set to work?</i>) (T. 198).</e><br/>','Tēra',NULL,'T');

Ka nui te tere o to koutou waka.—Kia tere mai te kaiwhakahoki mai i te korero. <e><m>Nga tangata e kaha ana, e ngutu tere ana ki te korero</m> (W.M. ix, 134).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>7.</b>&nbsp;<f>n.</f> <i>Shoal</i> of fish.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>8.</b>&nbsp;<i>Company of travellers</i>. <e><m>Te haerenga ki te teretere, ki roto te tere a Huakatoa, te rangatira</m> (P. 99).</e><br/> <br/><h2>terenga</h2><f>n.</f> <i>Place in which to swim or float</i>. <e><m>Ka rapu kainga hei terenga mo tana ika</m> (T. 68).</e><br/> <br/><h2>whakatere</h2><f>v.t.</f> <b>1.</b>&nbsp;<i>Buoy up</i>. <e><m>Ka tango ia i nga taha e ono hei whakatere mona</m> (T. 132).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;<i>Steer, navigate</i>, a canoe.<br/> <br/><h2>whakatetere</h2><f>v.t.</f> <i>Make to flow</i>. <e><m>Te whakateteretia mai he toto maringiringi</m> (M. 327).</e><br/> <br/><h2>teretere</h2><b>1.</b>&nbsp;<f>v.i.</f> <i>Be liquid, flow, run</i>.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;<i>Be spread out</i>. <e><m>Ko te rangi e teretere ana i runga o te whenua</m> (T. 16).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp;<i>Swim about</i>. <e><m>Tena kei te wai he parera teretere</m> (M. 182).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>4.</b>&nbsp;<f>n.</f> <i>Company of travellers</i>. <e><m>Ka u mai he teretere no Aotea ki Wharekawa, ki a Paka</m> (T. 143).</e><br/> <br/><h2>whakateretere</h2><f>v.t.</f> <b>1.</b>&nbsp;<i>Make to float</i>. Torona te hangi; ka kakā.—Ka torona ki te pungarehu, ka maoka, ka kainga. <e><m>Katahi ka tahuna te ahi, ka kā, ka toroa te toki ki runga ki te ahi</m> (W.M. x, 203.).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>12.</b>&nbsp;<i>Smooth</i> timber <i>with an adze</i>.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>13.</b>&nbsp;<f>n.</f> <i>Scout</i>. <e><m>Te taenga ki te one i Tirau, tera ka kitea mai e nga toro</m> (J. xx, 22).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>14.</b>&nbsp;The detachable portion of a fishing line, carrying the hooks, etc.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>15.</b>&nbsp;<e>In the expression <m>he toro tika</m>, <i>in a direct line, as the crow flies</i>.</e> <br/> <br/><h2>toronga</h2><f>n.</f> <i>Distant relatives</i>. A figurative expression taken from the shoots of a gourd running to a distance see <m>toro 1 above</m><br/> <br/><h2>whakatoro, whātoro</h2><b>1.</b>&nbsp;<f>v.t.</f> <i>Touch, make trial of</i>. <e><m>Whakatoro ana mai, ko tou wairua tonu</m> (M. 352).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;<i>Push forward, thrust, stretch out</i>. E whakatoro kau ana i te here i roto i nga pakawha o te rakau, kahore ano kia wero noa ki te manu.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp;<f>n.</f> A platform projecting from the top of the palisade of a <m>pa</m>, to enable the defenders to discharge missiles upon the heads of their assailants.<br/> <br/><h2>totoro</h2><b>1.</b>&nbsp;<f>v.i.</f> <i>Stretch forth</i>. Totoro mai te ringa.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;<i>Creep, crawl</i>. <e><m>Tu mumui te ngaro, totoro te iro</m> (M. 305).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp;<f>n.</f> <i>Cirsotrema zelebori</i>, a univalve mollusc.<br/> <br/><h2>torotoro</h2><b>1.</b>&nbsp;<f>v.i.</f> <i>Put forth the hands, act</i>. <e><m>Ka whakatika nga rangatira ki runga, ki te korero i te ata torotoro</m> (T. 150).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;<f>v.t.</f> <i>Spy out, reconnoitre</i>.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp;<i>Stir</i> a fire.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>4.</b>&nbsp;<f>n.</f> <i>Scout, advance guard</i>. Ko Turangapito ano te torotoro i mua o taua ope taua.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>5.</b>&nbsp;<i>Hawser, cable</i> for securing a canoe. He torotoro te ingoa o era taura o nga punga.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>6.</b>&nbsp; <i>Metrosideros perforata</i>, a climbing plant, the vines of which were used for lashing various things. It was also called <m>aka torotoro</m>.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>7.</b>&nbsp;An ant.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>8.</b>&nbsp;A garment. (obsolete.) = <m>parawai</m><br/> <br/><h2>whakatorotoro</h2><f>v.t.</f> <i>Press on, attack</i>. Ka mau te mahanga, hoatu rawa ki runga i te upoko; he ui anake ta tera, kihai i mau.—I uia te kaha i te kaki o te manu.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp;<i>Ask, enquire</i>, <e><m>Ka uia atu ki a ia, “Kei whea ra taku tuahine?”</m> (T. 42).</e> <e><m>Katahi ka ui mai te wahine nei, a Tukutuku, ka mea, “Kei whea te tangata e haere mai nei te rongo?</m> (T. 188).</e>   <m>Tupuna uia</m>, one whose descent has to be enquired, one of no account. <e><m>Tupuna uia, taurekareka</m> (M. 345).</e><br/> <br/><h2>whakaui</h2><b>1.</b>&nbsp;<f>v.t.</f> <i>Question</i>. Ka rere te whakaui a te tangata.<br/> <br/><h2>uiui</h2><f>v.t.</f> <i>Enquire for, interrogate</i>. <e><m>Kia uiui mai, “Ko wai tou ingoa?”</m> (M. 205).</e> <e><m>Katahi ka uiuia tetahi tangata tino manawanui o taua ope</m> (T. 154).</e> <e><m>Ka mutu nga uiuinga</m> (T. 42).</e><br/>','Ui',NULL,'U');

INSERT INTO "dictionary" VALUES(11544,'W','<f>consonant</f> <when>Pronounced as in English. In some words <m>w</m> is sometimes dropped after a syllable ending in <m>o</m> or <m>u</m>, as <m>koroai</m> = <m>korowai</m>, <m>kuare</m> = <m>kuware</m>; while on the other hand <m>w</m> is sometimes inserted after such a syllable as <m>arowa</m> = <m>aroa. W</m>is, in Maori, never followed by <m>o</m> or <m>u</m>.</when> <br/>','W',NULL,'W');

INSERT INTO "dictionary" VALUES(11799,'Wh','<f>consonant</f> <when>Represents the voiceless consonant corresponding with <m>w</m>, and is pronounced by emitting the breath sharply between the lips. It is a mistake to assimilate the sound to that of <i>f</i> in English, though this has become fashionable in recent years with some of the younger Maoris. In some words <m>wh</m> and <m>h</m> are interchangeable, as <m>kohatu, kowhatu; mahiti, mawhiti</m>. In a few words there is confusion between <m>wh</m> and <m>w</m>, but this may be due to the fact that in early works printed in Maori no distinction was made between the two, both being printed as <m>w. Wh</m> is never found in Maori followed by <m>o</m> or <m>u</m>.</when> <br/>','Wh',NULL,'W');

INSERT INTO "dictionary" VALUES(11848,'Whaka.','<f>causative prefix</f> <when>Probably connected with the previous word.</when> <b>1.</b>&nbsp;Combined with an intransitive verb, an adjective or participle to form an intransitive verb, it signifies a beginning of, or approach to, the action or condition indicated. <e><m>Po rua hoki a Tukutuku e whakatata ana ki a Paoa, kihai i tata</m> (T. 199).</e> <e><m>Na ka whakawhiti a Kupe i te moana o Raukawa, a ka whiti</m> (<i>Then Kupe set about crossing the straits of Raukawa, and crossed over</i> (T. 109).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;Combined with a noun to form an intransitive verb, it signifies the assumption of the character or form expressed by the noun. <e><m>Kua whakatangata taua kukupa</m> (T. 16).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp;As a strict causative it may combine with a verb, adjective, participle, or noun to form a transitive verb. <e><m>Katahi ano a Rupe ka whakakukupa i a ia</m> (<i>Made himself into a pigeon</i>) (T. 33).</e> <e><m>Kia nunui te tao, kaua e whakaririkitia</m> (<i>Don''t let them be made small</i>) (T. 118).</e> <e><m>E Kupe, e, whakahokia mai te waka ki a au</m> (<i>Make the canoe return to me</i>) (T. 109).</e>   Other varieties and shades of meaning will be found under the word to which <m>whaka</m> is prefixed in each case. see <m>whā (iv)</m><br/>','Whaka','ii','W');

(J. vii, 131)&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>6.</b>&nbsp;<i>Sleep doubled up</i>; a bad omen.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>7.</b>&nbsp;<i>Happen</i>; in the expression <m>whawhati tata</m>, sudden.<br/> <br/><h2>whatiwhati</h2><b>1.</b>&nbsp;<f>v.t.</f> <i>Break off</i> a number of things, <i>break into pieces, shatter</i>.<e><m>Ka whaka-tokia te mara, e waru nga kopura, whati-whatiia ana, ka toua</m> (T. 114).</e><e>He ra whatiwhati ko (A proverbial expression for <i>a day for hard work</i>).</e> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>2.</b>&nbsp;<i>Bend</i>, as the legs in running. <e><m>E mua, ata haere; e muri whatiwhati waewae</m> (P.).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>3.</b>&nbsp;<i>Collect, assemble</i>. <e><m>Katahi ka haere te tangata ki te whatiwhati ope mana.</m></e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>4.</b>&nbsp;<f>v.i.</f> <i>Come, come together</i>. <e><m>Whatiwhati mai nga iwi o ia wahi, o ia wahi.</m></e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>5.</b>&nbsp;<i>Be broken</i>. <e><m>Ka whatiwhati koa nga parirau o Rupe</m> (P. 46).</e>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>6.</b>&nbsp;<f>a.</f> <e><m>I tapu i te aha to uru whatiwhati?</m> (M. 391).</e> &nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<b>7.</b>&nbsp;<f>n.</f> <e><m>Taku whatiwhati ki ka riro</m> (M. 125).</e> <br/>','Whati',NULL,'W');
